headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the First Quarter 2010 Dover Corp. Earnings Conference Call. With us today are Bob Livingston, President and Chief Executive Officer of Dover Corp.; Brad Cerepak, Vice President and CFO of Dover Corp.; and Paul Goldberg, Treas
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to the First Quarter 2010 Dover Corp. Earnings Conference Call. With us today are Bob Livingston, President and Chief Executive Officer of Dover Corp.; Brad Cerepak, Vice President and CFO of Dover Corp.; and Paul Goldberg, Treasurer and Director of Investor Relations of Dover Corp. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to Mr. Paul Goldberg. Mr. Goldberg, please go ahead, sir.

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Christie. Good morning, and welcome to Dover's First Quarter Earnings Call. With me today are Bob Livingston, Dover's President and Chief Executive Officer; and Brad Cerepak, our CFO. Today's call will begin with comments from Bob and Brad on D
componenttext:
Thank you, Christie. Good morning, and welcome to Dover's First Quarter Earnings Call. With me today are Bob Livingston, Dover's President and Chief Executive Officer; and Brad Cerepak, our CFO. Today's call will begin with comments from Bob and Brad on Dover's first quarter operating and financial performance and our updated outlook for the rest of 2010. We will then open the call up to questions. And in the interest of time, we kindly ask that you limit yourself to one question with a follow-up.
Please note that our current earnings release, investor supplement and associated presentation can be found on our website, www.dovercorporation.com. This call will be available for playback through May 7 and the audio portion of this call will be archived on our website for three months. The replay telephone number is 800-642-1687. When accessing the playback, you'll need to supply the following reservation code, 66592109.
Before we get started, I'd like to remind everyone that our comments today, which are intended to supplement your understanding of Dover, may contain certain forward-looking statements that are inherently subject to uncertainties. We caution everyone to be guided in their analysis of Dover Corp. by referring to Form 10-K for a list of factors that could cause our results to differ from those anticipated in any such forward-looking statement. We also undertake no obligation to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statements except as required by law. We would also direct your attention to our website where considerably more information can be found. With that, I'd like to turn this call over to Bob.

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Paul. Good morning, everyone and thank you for joining us for this morning's conference call. The first quarter was much improved across Dover and better than anticipated. Revenue increased 15% over the last year and our orders were 41% above a we
componenttext:
Thanks, Paul. Good morning, everyone and thank you for joining us for this morning's conference call. The first quarter was much improved across Dover and better than anticipated. Revenue increased 15% over the last year and our orders were 41% above a weak first quarter of 2009. Our 2009 acquisitions contributed 5% revenue growth in the quarter. Positive trends noted in the second half of '09 continued in Electronic Technologies, Energy and Product ID, and business activity also improved in Fluid Solutions and Material Handling.
Clearly, we are seeing evidence of a global economic recovery across a wide portion of our portfolio and we expect these trends to benefit us next quarter and for the year. Thus, we have increased guidance for the year and Brad will discuss our updated outlook later in the call. 
With that, let's move to our first quarter results. Today, we reported first quarter earnings per share of $0.65, up 97% from last year. First quarter revenue was $1.6 billion, an increase of 15% over last year and 5% sequentially. First quarter revenue was stronger than expected at Fluid Management and Electronic Technologies, slightly better than expected at Industrial Products. Revenue at Engineered Systems was as anticipated and order rates were robust. The order rates at Engineered Systems have them well positioned for a strong seasonal upswing the next two quarters. Net earnings from continuing operations were $122 million, nearly double last year's result.
I was very pleased to see bookings accelerate as the quarter progressed. For the quarter, bookings were $1.8 billion, again, up 41% over the prior year and a 13% sequential improvement. For the second consecutive quarter, sequential bookings growth was double digit and the strength of those bookings was across a wide portion of our portfolio. Bookings increased at all segments on both a year-over-year and sequential basis. Book-to-bill finished at 1.12. Operating margin for the quarter was 15%, up 480 basis points. Margins improved at Industrial Products, Engineered Systems and Electronic Technologies, and remains strong at Fluid Management. Sequentially, margins improved at each segment.
These solid results reflect higher volume and the continuing benefits of restructuring actions taken in 2009. It was very gratifying to see how well our companies converted volume to earnings. In the first quarter, we generated free cash flow of $48 million, 3% of revenue. Our first quarter is traditionally the weakest in terms of cash flow generation. This quarter's cash flow also reflects an increase in working capital to support revenue growth. I remain confident that full-year free cash flow will be around 10% of revenue.
Our acquisition pipeline remains active as we continue to look for opportunities which complement our strong positions and diversify our geographic footprint. Though we did not close any deals in the first quarter, we remain confident we will complete some strategic add ons as the year unfolds. Now let me turn the call over to Brad for comments on our segment performance.

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bob. Good morning, everyone. I would like to first cover our first quarter segment performance and then discuss some additional financial information. I'd like to start on Slide 5. As Bob mentioned, sequential revenue increased 5% across Dover. Th
componenttext:
Thanks, Bob. Good morning, everyone. I would like to first cover our first quarter segment performance and then discuss some additional financial information. I'd like to start on Slide 5. As Bob mentioned, sequential revenue increased 5% across Dover. This performance was better than anticipated and better than our normal seasonal pattern. Revenue grew 13% sequentially at Fluid Management and 5% in Industrial Products, while Engineered Systems revenue increased 2%. Electronics Technologies' revenue was essentially flat. We were pleased with this performance as Electronic Technologies' first quarter tends to be seasonally weaker than the fourth. From a bookings perspective, we saw sequential improvements at all four segments. Also of note, March bookings were by far the strongest month of the quarter.
Turning to Slide 6. Industrial Products posted revenue of $429 million and $51 million of earnings. Though revenue was down 1% from last year, earnings improved 48%. This strong earnings performance was a result of volume improvement at some of our higher gross margin operating companies and the benefit of our prior restructuring efforts. Bookings were $435 million, an increase of 32%, indicating improving trends in most end markets. Industrial Products produced a quarterly operating margin of 11.9%, which was up 400 basis points from last year and 170 basis points sequentially. Again, our earlier rightsizing actions continue to put this segment in a strong position to leverage any market recovery.
With respect to our Material Handling platform, sales increased 1% to $189 million, while earnings increased 135% driven by strong results at Warn and DE-STA-CO. This resulted in platform margins up over 800 basis points from 2009. For the quarter, bookings were $204 million, an increase of 72% over last year and 13% sequentially, yielding a book-to-bill of 1.08. North American construction trends are modestly improving and our order rates in our Military Winch business are strong. With respect to our Mobile Equipment platform, sales were $240 million, down 3% from last year while earnings increased 8%. Margins increased 150 basis points, capitalizing on improving automotive service markets and the aggressive restructuring actions and business integrations completed in 2009. Bookings were $231 million in the quarter, an increase of 10% over the prior year, but down 9% sequentially reflecting lumpy military orders. As discussed last quarter, the commercial aerospace and core petroleum and bulk trailer markets remain challenged and are having a negative effect on platform growth.
Turning to Slide 7. At Engineered Systems, sales were $484 million, an increase of 21% and segment earnings increased 27% to $55 million. Bookings for the quarter were $589 million, an increase of 43% over the prior year and a 21% sequential improvement, resulting in a book-to-bill of 1.22. The year-over-year growth in revenue is largely attributable to strength in Product ID and acquisitions of Tyler and Barker. For the quarter, operating margin was 11.3%, a 50 basis point improvement over last year. The margin performance was the result of solid Product ID leverage, partially offset by product mix at Hill PHOENIX and a weak restaurant equipment market served by Unified Brands.
With respect our Product Identification platform, Markem-Imaje continued to benefit from solid market dynamics, both in the fast-moving consumer goods and industrial end markets. This trend was partially offset by some weakness at Datamax-O'Neil. Despite that, first quarter sales were $212 million, an increase of 20%, including 5% from FX. Earnings increased 69% and margins increased over 500 basis points compared to last year. We expect continuing improvements in these end markets supported by a book-to-bill of 1.04.
The Engineered Products platform posted an increase of revenue of 22%, to $272 million, although earnings declined 3% resulting in margins declining 260 basis points. The primary drivers were a weak product mix at Hill PHOENIX in the first half of the quarter and weak market conditions and lower volume at Unified Brands. The 2009 acquisitions of Barker and Tyler provided revenue of $57 million in the first quarter. Engineered Products bookings were $368 million, an increase of 56% over the prior-year period and 40% sequentially for a book-to-bill of 1.35. This seasonal improvement is higher than normal and largely driven by Hill PHOENIX with a book-to-bill of 1.42. As a result, the second and third quarter should be very strong for our Hill PHOENIX business.
Moving to Slide 8. At Fluid Management, both sales and earnings increased 15% to $381 million and $87 million affectively. Bookings were $388 million, an increase of 32% from the prior year and 12% sequentially, resulting in a book-to-bill of 1.02. First quarter operating margin was 22.8%, flat with last year but a 270 basis point sequential improvement. We continue to see signs of improving end markets in this segment. Our Energy platform is highly correlated with the improving North American rig count, which increased 20% from year end. Platform revenue increased 16% to $205 million while earnings were 18% higher. Margin improved 50 basis points from the prior-year period on higher volume and the benefits of restructuring. Quarterly bookings were $209 million, an increase of 46% year-over-year and 18% sequentially. Book-to-bill was 1.02, reflecting solid dynamics in most served end markets. The Fluid Solutions platform generated revenue of $176 million, an increase of 14%. Earnings increased 25%, resulting in 180 basis point margin improvement. Bookings increased 19% year-over-year to $179 million and increased 6% sequentially. We are beginning to see modest but broad improvement in most of this platform's served markets.
Now turning to Slide 9. Electronic Technology end markets were up significantly year-over-year, with high demand for electronic assembly equipment and MEMS microphones. Revenue was $291 million, an increase of 36% over 2009. Earnings were $45 million, a tremendous improvement over the $12 million loss incurred last year. Operating margin was 15.4%, driven by significantly higher volume and the benefits of earlier restructuring. Book-to-bill continues to be strong at 1.23. Our electronic assembly equipment companies continue to see an improving order book for the fourth consecutive quarter. In fact, order rates increased 33% sequentially. We expect the favorable climate in electronic assembly markets to continue in the near term. These favorable market conditions resulted in a book-to-bill of 1.44 for these companies. It was another solid quarter for our communication components companies, primarily reflecting strength at Knowles and improving conditions in the telecom infrastructure markets. Bookings continued to be strong with a book-to-bill of 1.11. 
Having reviewed the segments, I now would like to briefly provide some additional financial data, starting on Slide 10. First quarter net interest expense of $27 million was up $5 million from last year but in line with our full-year guidance. The first quarter result reflected lower returns on invested balances. Our net debt to total capitalization was 19.4%, a 100 basis point increase from year-end 2009 due to increases in working capital. Turning to taxes, our first quarter tax rate was 31.4%, 370 basis points below last year's rate due to favorable geographic mix. We still expect the full year rate to be in the range of 29% to 30%. Corporate expense for the first quarter was $33 million, up $9 million from last year and in line with our full-year expectations.
Turning to Slide 11. As discussed, the first quarter was quite strong for us both in terms of revenue and bookings. We have raised our full-year outlook for organic revenue growth to reflect the current demand environment. We now expect organic revenue growth to be in the range of 7% to 10%. Breaking this down by segment, Industrial Products revenue should increase 1% to 4%, Engineered Systems should grow at 5% to 7% for the year, Fluid Solutions overall revenue growth should be in the 10% to 12% range, and Electronic Technologies should grow revenue in the high teens to the low 20% range.
We expect acquisition-related growth to be roughly 3% for transactions completed in 2009. The impact of FX is assumed to be approximately neutral for the full year. All other items remain principally unchanged from our January call. Based on these revised revenue expectations, we are now forecasting 2010 EPS to be in the range of $2.70 to $2.95.
Now let's go to the full-year earnings bridge on Slide 12. As you would expect, volume is the primary driver of the increase in earnings. Volume, product mix and pricing should improve earnings $0.56 to $0.80, this compares favorably with our range of $0.22 to $0.46. Restructuring and productivity continue to be a big driver of EPS growth for us in 2010, primarily due to the absence of restructuring costs and carryover benefits. Our 2009 acquisitions will deliver $0.10 and our tax rate impact is a function of our improved earnings forecast. All other categories are largely unchanged from our last call. Based on our revenue range, we would expect full-year EPS growth of 36% to 48%.
With that, I'd like to turn the call back over to Bob.

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Brad. Good review. I was pleased with our performance in the first quarter, especially with regard to revenue and bookings growth, conversion and operating margin. We expect to see an even stronger second quarter, partly due to seasonality. While
componenttext:
Thanks, Brad. Good review. I was pleased with our performance in the first quarter, especially with regard to revenue and bookings growth, conversion and operating margin. We expect to see an even stronger second quarter, partly due to seasonality. While line of sight is somewhat limited with regard to the back half of 2010, we also expect those year-over-year comparisons to be favorable. Lastly, as we have begun to recover from the depths of the recession, I have been encouraged to hear multiple success stories from our business leaders with respect to market share gains, new product launches, traction and our supply chain initiative, and the excellent performance of our 2009 acquisitions. We believe we are well-positioned in our markets and our business leaders are focused on growth. I am confident they will deliver.
Before I close, I'd like to once again acknowledge the tremendous efforts of our operating companies with regard to margin performance. I was both encouraged and quite proud by how quickly our operating companies drove margins back to 15%. This puts us on a solid footing to deliver full-year margins on par with prior peak levels. With that, I'll turn it back to Paul for questions.

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bob. Before we turn it over to Christie to compile questions, I just want to remind everybody again, so that we can answer everybody's question, if you would limit your questions to one with a follow-up. Thanks. And at this point, Christie, could
componenttext: Thanks, Bob. Before we turn it over to Christie to compile questions, I just want to remind everybody again, so that we can answer everybody's question, if you would limit your questions to one with a follow-up. Thanks. And at this point, Christie, could you compile the questions?

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010

componenttext: Hey guys, one of the things that really surprised us versus our model and there's several things, but when you think about this $0.50 of net benefit from restructuring and productivity. And help me understand at least, is that based on kind of current volumes that you saw in 1Q? Does that number go up as volumes go up just given that the fixed cost leverage there or is that -- I guess, I just don't know how that number is compiled?

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that's right. We are seeing more benefits than we last estimated in our previous guidance. And I would say that's principally due to again, being able to leverage the existing workforce we have. We haven't added that many heads through the f
componenttext: Well, I think that's right. We are seeing more benefits than we last estimated in our previous guidance. And I would say that's principally due to again, being able to leverage the existing workforce we have. We haven't added that many heads through the first quarter. That could change as the year progresses. But right now, we're seeing benefits improving. I think we said last time, carryover was 35 million to 40 million. We're seeing it now closer to 60 million.

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: On Electronic Technologies, it's always been a tough business for those of us in industrial end to understand. How do you think about how you grew versus the market? I mean, I suspect there's been some real share shifts in MEMS, but is there a way to kind
componenttext: On Electronic Technologies, it's always been a tough business for those of us in industrial end to understand. How do you think about how you grew versus the market? I mean, I suspect there's been some real share shifts in MEMS, but is there a way to kind of measure market growth, think about your performance versus the market or is this a rising tide lifts all boats and the market has really come back strong too?

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think it's a little bit of both, Scott. You need to look at Electronic Technologies and look at the two different groupings, communication component companies versus the assembly and test companies. The growth rate in the assembly and test companies has
componenttext: I think it's a little bit of both, Scott. You need to look at Electronic Technologies and look at the two different groupings, communication component companies versus the assembly and test companies. The growth rate in the assembly and test companies has been quite strong not just in the first quarter but during the second half of '09 versus the trough there in the first half of '09. That level of growth, that level of change, I would say, is not unusual or abnormal when you come out of a low point in the electronics cycle. I think you're real question is are we capturing share or are we just riding with the market? I think in some targeted areas we're capturing share, MEMS. I would point to one as we continue to see our growth in MEMS outpace the growth in the cell phone market. I think in some new product launches within the assembly and test companies, the product launches have been quite successful.

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: When you think about a book-to-bill in this particular business, I mean how much visibility do you have? Is it a very short cycle of time or are some of these orders longer-term orders?
componenttext: When you think about a book-to-bill in this particular business, I mean how much visibility do you have? Is it a very short cycle of time or are some of these orders longer-term orders?

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would say that the bulk of our orders are going to be delivered within 12 weeks of order. So I would label them as short cycle. And Scott, don't predict or don't model another book-to-bill at 1.4 in the second quarter.
componenttext: I would say that the bulk of our orders are going to be delivered within 12 weeks of order. So I would label them as short cycle. And Scott, don't predict or don't model another book-to-bill at 1.4 in the second quarter.

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes on the line of Nigel Coe with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes on the line of Nigel Coe with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to echo Scott's points about the year, strong start to the year there. So just semiconductor and North American gas, there is some concern about the second half maybe towards the back end of year, about those the two markets. First of all, wha
componenttext: Just wanted to echo Scott's points about the year, strong start to the year there. So just semiconductor and North American gas, there is some concern about the second half maybe towards the back end of year, about those the two markets. First of all, what is your view on that? And secondly, to what extent have you built that into your model?

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I guess we would fear those concerns, and I think we have built them into our model. If you look at our revised guidance on growth of the year, 7% to 10% organic, we have 7% in the first quarter. We've got an easier comp going into the second quarte
componenttext: Well, I guess we would fear those concerns, and I think we have built them into our model. If you look at our revised guidance on growth of the year, 7% to 10% organic, we have 7% in the first quarter. We've got an easier comp going into the second quarter, Nigel. But even with that, I will tell you that our organic growth forecast for the second quarter is mid-teens. We take that down significantly in the second half even though it's still favorable. We're looking at organic growth comparisons to the second half of last year of mid-single digits. So why? You've touched on the two whys, the Electronics business and our Energy business. With respect to Energy, the guys had a great start here to the year. We had a good first quarter. We're modeling that to essentially go sideways for the balance of the year. We take some of steam off the engine, so to speak, in Electronic Technologies in the second half. There is some seasonality that we expect to return to that business in the fourth quarter. I think we're recognizing that in our modeling.

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then the 15% margin, I mean that's up to your long-term margin goal. What does this tell us about the potential for long-term margins, 15% margins in the first quarter of a real recovery, where do you think margins can go longer term ?
componenttext: And then the 15% margin, I mean that's up to your long-term margin goal. What does this tell us about the potential for long-term margins, 15% margins in the first quarter of a real recovery, where do you think margins can go longer term ?

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, longer term, let's look at the next couple of years instead of the next seven. We were very pleased with the margin performance in the first quarter. And as I said in my prepared comments, I think it sets us up well to return to our peak margin perf
componenttext: Well, longer term, let's look at the next couple of years instead of the next seven. We were very pleased with the margin performance in the first quarter. And as I said in my prepared comments, I think it sets us up well to return to our peak margin performance, and we'll achieve that this year. It'll be between 15% to 16% operating margins. I think we do have some upside beyond that. It's something that we're discussing and looking at quite diligently across the businesses. But for modeling purposes, within a couple of years, I see us very capable of being at 17% margins or perhaps a bit better.

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Bob, Dover was one of the most aggressive companies at taking out capacity and headcount in the downturn. And as we're rolling into some of these book-to-bill numbers in an accelerating economy for a lot of your businesses, how are you feeling about capac
componenttext: Bob, Dover was one of the most aggressive companies at taking out capacity and headcount in the downturn. And as we're rolling into some of these book-to-bill numbers in an accelerating economy for a lot of your businesses, how are you feeling about capacity generally within Dover? And just how does that dovetail with sort of your actions and just your ability to kind of, I think, satisfy demand in the near term? How should we be thinking about this, and how are you thinking about it?

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, there's two parts to the capacity response or response to the increasing orders. One is our workforce. The second part is our supply chain. And I think you can look at the data that's been shared here. Headcount was up in the first quarter. I think
componenttext: Well, there's two parts to the capacity response or response to the increasing orders. One is our workforce. The second part is our supply chain. And I think you can look at the data that's been shared here. Headcount was up in the first quarter. I think we added about 700 employees in the first quarter, John. Most of them, more than half of the employment increase in the first half was in Asia. So we're not reluctant to add employees and bring them back as the business conditions warrant or dictate. Supply chain is a bit of a different issue. We have seen it during the first quarter, and I expect we would continue to see it in the early part here in the second quarter. Some constraints on the supply chain, especially around the Electronics area. And the other parts of the business, I wouldn't label that as a significant concern.

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Bob, just talking about initiatives, could you just remind us where things stand on that point? Meaning maybe you can talk a little bit about supply rationalization. I mean the rate of recovery being so strong, has that put some of these activities on hol
componenttext: Bob, just talking about initiatives, could you just remind us where things stand on that point? Meaning maybe you can talk a little bit about supply rationalization. I mean the rate of recovery being so strong, has that put some of these activities on hold as you try and just manage for a recovery versus some of the pruning? And just maybe remind us what the cost benefits are this year to next year.

componenttext: Let me respond to the more general question, are we putting any of our activities on hold? And the answer is no, John. componenttext: Alright. Well, you asked a question, but you make a statement. I don't think I said that it improved. I said it is still quite active. componenttextpreview: Let me answer the question just overall for Dover. When we originally put out guidance back in January, we were assuming there was going to be some price-cost pressure. And at that time, we said it would be 60 to 75 basis points impact on margin. Today, w
componenttext: Let me answer the question just overall for Dover. When we originally put out guidance back in January, we were assuming there was going to be some price-cost pressure. And at that time, we said it would be 60 to 75 basis points impact on margin. Today, we see that as a little bit higher, let's say, we're estimating now in this guidance about 100 basis points, mostly all driven by commodities. Now I would then go one step further to say it's more prevalent in some of our businesses than others where we have a higher spend on commodities. But again, you're talking about a pretty small impact, mostly second-half weighted.

componenttextpreview: Well, I think we've clearly have seen that at the DEK business with respect to their traditional core printers. And one of the more interesting product launch successes we've had over the last 18 months was a product launch in the depths of the recession,
componenttext: Well, I think we've clearly have seen that at the DEK business with respect to their traditional core printers. And one of the more interesting product launch successes we've had over the last 18 months was a product launch in the depths of the recession, in the first quarter of last year by DEK of a solar printing product offering that has shown very, very strong growth over the last 15 months. And order activity there was quite strong in the first quarter. And within the Test business, we've seen very strong order rates at Multitest in their first quarter and believe we're taking share there.

componenttext: Let me start first sort of the revenue split for the first quarter, and it's probably not much different than it was during most of last year. North America, and this is both the U.S. and Canada. So under North America, it was 60% of our revenue; Europe, about 18%; Asia, 14% to 15%; Latin America 4% to 5%; and I know I'm missing 2 or 3 points. Let's call it other. I think the second part was growth. Am I picking that up through, Alex?

componenttext: Well, yes. The other companies are saying that, that North American part and Western Europe is relatively weak. And the real strength is in Asia and Latin America.

componenttext: The first quarter versus a year ago, North America growth was about 9%. Europe was about 8%. Latin America was about 40%, and Asia was about 55%. Of that huge number in Asia, 55%, it was 39% or 40% in China.

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: So what can you do now to capitalize on those kinds of trends going forward? I mean are you shifting some emphasis to those countries that are rapidly growing or are you leaving that up to individual units or what?
componenttext: So what can you do now to capitalize on those kinds of trends going forward? I mean are you shifting some emphasis to those countries that are rapidly growing or are you leaving that up to individual units or what?

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, both. And it's not something we're responding to this quarter. It's something we've been working on for the past 18 months. And again, not to overemphasize this, but it is a key part. It was the effort we made starting in the second half of '08 that
componenttext: Well, both. And it's not something we're responding to this quarter. It's something we've been working on for the past 18 months. And again, not to overemphasize this, but it is a key part. It was the effort we made starting in the second half of '08 that really did complete it last year was the establishment of our regional headquarters in China, which is providing a fair amount of infrastructure and assistance. And as we went through the downturn and did our restructuring in the first half of last year, we did as we closed some manufacturing facilities in North America and Europe. At the same time, we were bringing up some new facilities in Asia in anticipation of the recovery of the economy. And we think it's benefited us. We'll continue to do that.

componenttext: No, I agree with that. componenttext: Well, that's part of it. But you also have to appreciate that our entire Energy business is not directly correlated to rig count deployment. Obviously, our Sucker Rod business is pretty tightly correlated, as well as U.S. Synthetics. But U.S. Synthetics business is also quite international, so it is not quite as dependent on North American rig count activity as perhaps Norris sucker rods.

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the First Quarter 2010 Dover Corp. Earnings Conference Call. With us today are Bob Livingston, President and Chief Executive Officer of Dover Corp.; Brad Cerepak, Vice President and CFO of Dover Corp.; and Paul Goldberg, Treas
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to the First Quarter 2010 Dover Corp. Earnings Conference Call. With us today are Bob Livingston, President and Chief Executive Officer of Dover Corp.; Brad Cerepak, Vice President and CFO of Dover Corp.; and Paul Goldberg, Treasurer and Director of Investor Relations of Dover Corp. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to Mr. Paul Goldberg. Mr. Goldberg, please go ahead, sir.

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Christie. Good morning, and welcome to Dover's First Quarter Earnings Call. With me today are Bob Livingston, Dover's President and Chief Executive Officer; and Brad Cerepak, our CFO. Today's call will begin with comments from Bob and Brad on D
componenttext:
Thank you, Christie. Good morning, and welcome to Dover's First Quarter Earnings Call. With me today are Bob Livingston, Dover's President and Chief Executive Officer; and Brad Cerepak, our CFO. Today's call will begin with comments from Bob and Brad on Dover's first quarter operating and financial performance and our updated outlook for the rest of 2010. We will then open the call up to questions. And in the interest of time, we kindly ask that you limit yourself to one question with a follow-up.
Please note that our current earnings release, investor supplement and associated presentation can be found on our website, www.dovercorporation.com. This call will be available for playback through May 7 and the audio portion of this call will be archived on our website for three months. The replay telephone number is 800-642-1687. When accessing the playback, you'll need to supply the following reservation code, 66592109.
Before we get started, I'd like to remind everyone that our comments today, which are intended to supplement your understanding of Dover, may contain certain forward-looking statements that are inherently subject to uncertainties. We caution everyone to be guided in their analysis of Dover Corp. by referring to Form 10-K for a list of factors that could cause our results to differ from those anticipated in any such forward-looking statement. We also undertake no obligation to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statements except as required by law. We would also direct your attention to our website where considerably more information can be found. With that, I'd like to turn this call over to Bob.

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Paul. Good morning, everyone and thank you for joining us for this morning's conference call. The first quarter was much improved across Dover and better than anticipated. Revenue increased 15% over the last year and our orders were 41% above a we
componenttext:
Thanks, Paul. Good morning, everyone and thank you for joining us for this morning's conference call. The first quarter was much improved across Dover and better than anticipated. Revenue increased 15% over the last year and our orders were 41% above a weak first quarter of 2009. Our 2009 acquisitions contributed 5% revenue growth in the quarter. Positive trends noted in the second half of '09 continued in Electronic Technologies, Energy and Product ID, and business activity also improved in Fluid Solutions and Material Handling.
Clearly, we are seeing evidence of a global economic recovery across a wide portion of our portfolio and we expect these trends to benefit us next quarter and for the year. Thus, we have increased guidance for the year and Brad will discuss our updated outlook later in the call. 
With that, let's move to our first quarter results. Today, we reported first quarter earnings per share of $0.65, up 97% from last year. First quarter revenue was $1.6 billion, an increase of 15% over last year and 5% sequentially. First quarter revenue was stronger than expected at Fluid Management and Electronic Technologies, slightly better than expected at Industrial Products. Revenue at Engineered Systems was as anticipated and order rates were robust. The order rates at Engineered Systems have them well positioned for a strong seasonal upswing the next two quarters. Net earnings from continuing operations were $122 million, nearly double last year's result.
I was very pleased to see bookings accelerate as the quarter progressed. For the quarter, bookings were $1.8 billion, again, up 41% over the prior year and a 13% sequential improvement. For the second consecutive quarter, sequential bookings growth was double digit and the strength of those bookings was across a wide portion of our portfolio. Bookings increased at all segments on both a year-over-year and sequential basis. Book-to-bill finished at 1.12. Operating margin for the quarter was 15%, up 480 basis points. Margins improved at Industrial Products, Engineered Systems and Electronic Technologies, and remains strong at Fluid Management. Sequentially, margins improved at each segment.
These solid results reflect higher volume and the continuing benefits of restructuring actions taken in 2009. It was very gratifying to see how well our companies converted volume to earnings. In the first quarter, we generated free cash flow of $48 million, 3% of revenue. Our first quarter is traditionally the weakest in terms of cash flow generation. This quarter's cash flow also reflects an increase in working capital to support revenue growth. I remain confident that full-year free cash flow will be around 10% of revenue.
Our acquisition pipeline remains active as we continue to look for opportunities which complement our strong positions and diversify our geographic footprint. Though we did not close any deals in the first quarter, we remain confident we will complete some strategic add ons as the year unfolds. Now let me turn the call over to Brad for comments on our segment performance.

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bob. Good morning, everyone. I would like to first cover our first quarter segment performance and then discuss some additional financial information. I'd like to start on Slide 5. As Bob mentioned, sequential revenue increased 5% across Dover. Th
componenttext:
Thanks, Bob. Good morning, everyone. I would like to first cover our first quarter segment performance and then discuss some additional financial information. I'd like to start on Slide 5. As Bob mentioned, sequential revenue increased 5% across Dover. This performance was better than anticipated and better than our normal seasonal pattern. Revenue grew 13% sequentially at Fluid Management and 5% in Industrial Products, while Engineered Systems revenue increased 2%. Electronics Technologies' revenue was essentially flat. We were pleased with this performance as Electronic Technologies' first quarter tends to be seasonally weaker than the fourth. From a bookings perspective, we saw sequential improvements at all four segments. Also of note, March bookings were by far the strongest month of the quarter.
Turning to Slide 6. Industrial Products posted revenue of $429 million and $51 million of earnings. Though revenue was down 1% from last year, earnings improved 48%. This strong earnings performance was a result of volume improvement at some of our higher gross margin operating companies and the benefit of our prior restructuring efforts. Bookings were $435 million, an increase of 32%, indicating improving trends in most end markets. Industrial Products produced a quarterly operating margin of 11.9%, which was up 400 basis points from last year and 170 basis points sequentially. Again, our earlier rightsizing actions continue to put this segment in a strong position to leverage any market recovery.
With respect to our Material Handling platform, sales increased 1% to $189 million, while earnings increased 135% driven by strong results at Warn and DE-STA-CO. This resulted in platform margins up over 800 basis points from 2009. For the quarter, bookings were $204 million, an increase of 72% over last year and 13% sequentially, yielding a book-to-bill of 1.08. North American construction trends are modestly improving and our order rates in our Military Winch business are strong. With respect to our Mobile Equipment platform, sales were $240 million, down 3% from last year while earnings increased 8%. Margins increased 150 basis points, capitalizing on improving automotive service markets and the aggressive restructuring actions and business integrations completed in 2009. Bookings were $231 million in the quarter, an increase of 10% over the prior year, but down 9% sequentially reflecting lumpy military orders. As discussed last quarter, the commercial aerospace and core petroleum and bulk trailer markets remain challenged and are having a negative effect on platform growth.
Turning to Slide 7. At Engineered Systems, sales were $484 million, an increase of 21% and segment earnings increased 27% to $55 million. Bookings for the quarter were $589 million, an increase of 43% over the prior year and a 21% sequential improvement, resulting in a book-to-bill of 1.22. The year-over-year growth in revenue is largely attributable to strength in Product ID and acquisitions of Tyler and Barker. For the quarter, operating margin was 11.3%, a 50 basis point improvement over last year. The margin performance was the result of solid Product ID leverage, partially offset by product mix at Hill PHOENIX and a weak restaurant equipment market served by Unified Brands.
With respect to our Product Identification platform, Markem-Imaje continued to benefit from solid market dynamics, both in the fast-moving consumer goods and industrial end markets. This strength was partially offset by some weakness at Datamax-O'Neil. Despite that, first quarter sales were $212 million, an increase of 20%, including 5% from FX. Earnings increased 69% and margins increased over 500 basis points compared to last year. We expect continuing improvements in these end markets supported by a book-to-bill of 1.04.
The Engineered Products platform posted an increase of revenue of 22%, to $272 million, although earnings declined 3% resulting in margins declining 260 basis points. The primary drivers were a weak product mix at Hill PHOENIX in the first half of the quarter and weak market conditions and lower volume at Unified Brands. The 2009 acquisitions of Barker and Tyler provided revenue of $57 million in the first quarter. Engineered Products bookings were $368 million, an increase of 56% over the prior-year period and 40% sequentially for a book-to-bill of 1.35. This seasonal improvement is higher than normal and largely driven by Hill PHOENIX with a book-to-bill of 1.42. As a result, the second and third quarter should be very strong for our Hill PHOENIX business.
Moving to Slide 8. At Fluid Management, both sales and earnings increased 15% to $381 million and $87 million respectively. Bookings were $388 million, an increase of 32% from the prior year and 12% sequentially, resulting in a book-to-bill of 1.02. First quarter operating margin was 22.8%, flat with last year but a 270 basis point sequential improvement. We continue to see signs of improving end markets in this segment. Our Energy platform is highly correlated with the improving North American rig count, which increased 20% from year end. Platform revenue increased 16% to $205 million while earnings were 18% higher. Margin improved 50 basis points from the prior-year period on higher volume and the benefits of restructuring. Quarterly bookings were $209 million, an increase of 46% year-over-year and 18% sequentially. Book-to-bill was 1.02, reflecting solid dynamics in most served end markets. The Fluid Solutions platform generated revenue of $176 million, an increase of 14%. Earnings increased 25%, resulting in 180 basis point margin improvement. Bookings increased 19% year-over-year to $179 million and increased 6% sequentially. We are beginning to see modest but broad improvement in most of this platform's served markets.
Now turning to Slide 9. Electronic Technology end markets were up significantly year-over-year, with high demand for electronic assembly equipment and MEMS microphones. Revenue was $291 million, an increase of 36% over 2009. Earnings were $45 million, a tremendous improvement over the $12 million loss incurred last year. Operating margin was 15.4%, driven by significantly higher volume and the benefits of earlier restructuring. Book-to-bill continues to be strong at 1.23. Our electronic assembly equipment companies continue to see an improving order book for the fourth consecutive quarter. In fact, order rates increased 33% sequentially. We expect the favorable climate in electronic assembly markets to continue in the near term. These favorable market conditions resulted in a book-to-bill of 1.44 for these companies. It was another solid quarter for our communication components companies, primarily reflecting strength at Knowles and improving conditions in the telecom infrastructure markets. Bookings continued to be strong with a book-to-bill of 1.11. 
Having reviewed the segments, I now would like to briefly provide some additional financial data, starting on Slide 10. First quarter net interest expense of $27 million was up $5 million from last year but in line with our full-year guidance. The first quarter result reflected lower returns on invested balances. Our net debt to total capitalization was 19.4%, a 100 basis point increase from year-end 2009 due to increases in working capital. Turning to taxes, our first quarter tax rate was 31.4%, 370 basis points below last year's rate due to favorable geographic mix. We still expect the full year rate to be in the range of 29% to 30%. Corporate expense for the first quarter was $33 million, up $9 million from last year and in line with our full-year expectations.
Turning to Slide 11. As discussed, the first quarter was quite strong for us both in terms of revenue and bookings. We have raised our full-year outlook for organic revenue growth to reflect the current demand environment. We now expect organic revenue growth to be in the range of 7% to 10%. Breaking this down by segment, Industrial Products revenue should increase 1% to 4%, Engineered Systems should grow at 5% to 7% for the year, Fluid Solutions overall revenue growth should be in the 10% to 12% range, and Electronic Technologies should grow revenue in the high teens to the low 20% range.
We expect acquisition-related growth to be roughly 3% for transactions completed in 2009. The impact of FX is assumed to be approximately neutral for the full year. All other items remain principally unchanged from our January call. Based on these revised revenue expectations, we are now forecasting 2010 EPS to be in the range of $2.70 to $2.95.
Now let's go to the full-year earnings bridge on Slide 12. As you would expect, volume is the primary driver of the increase in earnings. Volume, product mix and pricing should improve earnings $0.56 to $0.80, this compares favorably with our range of $0.22 to $0.46. Restructuring and productivity continue to be a big driver of EPS growth for us in 2010, primarily due to the absence of restructuring costs and carryover benefits. Our 2009 acquisitions will deliver $0.10 and our tax rate impact is a function of our improved earnings forecast. All other categories are largely unchanged from our last call. Based on our revenue range, we would expect full-year EPS growth of 36% to 48%.
With that, I'd like to turn the call back over to Bob.

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Brad. Good review. I was pleased with our performance in the first quarter, especially with regard to revenue and bookings growth, conversion and operating margin. We expect to see an even stronger second quarter, partly due to seasonality. While
componenttext:
Thanks, Brad. Good review. I was pleased with our performance in the first quarter, especially with regard to revenue and bookings growth, conversion and operating margin. We expect to see an even stronger second quarter, partly due to seasonality. While line of sight is somewhat limited with regard to the back half of 2010, we also expect those year-over-year comparisons to be favorable. Lastly, as we have begun to recover from the depths of the recession, I have been encouraged to hear multiple success stories from our business leaders with respect to market share gains, new product launches, traction and our supply chain initiative, and the excellent performance of our 2009 acquisitions. We believe we are well-positioned in our markets and our business leaders are focused on growth. I am confident they will deliver.
Before I close, I'd like to once again acknowledge the tremendous efforts of our operating companies with regard to margin performance. I was both encouraged and quite proud by how quickly our operating companies drove margins back to 15%. This puts us on a solid footing to deliver full-year margins on par with prior peak levels. With that, I'll turn it back to Paul for questions.

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bob. Before we turn it over to Christie to compile questions, I just want to remind everybody again, so that we can answer everybody's question, if you would limit your questions to one with a follow-up. Thanks. And at this point, Christie, could
componenttext: Thanks, Bob. Before we turn it over to Christie to compile questions, I just want to remind everybody again, so that we can answer everybody's question, if you would limit your questions to one with a follow-up. Thanks. And at this point, Christie, could you compile the questions?

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hey guys, one of the things that really surprised us versus our model and there's several things, but when you think about this $0.50 of net benefit from restructuring and productivity. And help me understand at least, is that based on kind of current vol
componenttext: Hey guys, one of the things that really surprised us versus our model and there's several things, but when you think about this $0.50 of net benefit from restructuring and productivity. And help me understand at least, is that based on kind of current volumes that you saw in 1Q? Does that number go up as volumes go up just given that the fixed cost leverage there or is that -- I guess, I just don't know how that number is compiled?

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that's right. We are seeing more benefits than we last estimated in our previous guidance. And I would say that's principally due to again, being able to leverage the existing workforce we have. We haven't added that many heads through the f
componenttext: Well, I think that's right. We are seeing more benefits than we last estimated in our previous guidance. And I would say that's principally due to again, being able to leverage the existing workforce we have. We haven't added that many heads through the first quarter. That could change as the year progresses. But right now, we're seeing benefits improving. I think we said last time, carryover was 35 million to 40 million. We're seeing it now closer to 60 million.

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: On Electronic Technologies, it's always been a tough business for those of us in industrial end to understand. How do you think about how you grew versus the market? I mean, I suspect there's been some real share shifts in MEMS, but is there a way to kind
componenttext: On Electronic Technologies, it's always been a tough business for those of us in industrial end to understand. How do you think about how you grew versus the market? I mean, I suspect there's been some real share shifts in MEMS, but is there a way to kind of measure market growth, think about your performance versus the market or is this a rising tide lifts all boats and the market has really come back strong too?

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think it's a little bit of both, Scott. You need to look at Electronic Technologies and look at the two different groupings, communication component companies versus the assembly and test companies. The growth rate in the assembly and test companies has
componenttext: I think it's a little bit of both, Scott. You need to look at Electronic Technologies and look at the two different groupings, communication component companies versus the assembly and test companies. The growth rate in the assembly and test companies has been quite strong not just in the first quarter but during the second half of '09 versus the trough there in the first half of '09. That level of growth, that level of change, I would say, is not unusual or abnormal when you come out of a low point in the electronics cycle. I think you're real question is are we capturing share or are we just riding with the market? I think in some targeted areas we're capturing share, MEMS. I would point to one as we continue to see our growth in MEMS outpace the growth in the cell phone market. I think in some new product launches within the assembly and test companies, the product launches have been quite successful.

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: When you think about a book-to-bill in this particular business, I mean how much visibility do you have? Is it a very short cycle of time or are some of these orders longer-term orders?
componenttext: When you think about a book-to-bill in this particular business, I mean how much visibility do you have? Is it a very short cycle of time or are some of these orders longer-term orders?

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would say that the bulk of our orders are going to be delivered within 12 weeks of order. So I would label them as short cycle. And Scott, don't predict or don't model another book-to-bill at 1.4 in the second quarter.
componenttext: I would say that the bulk of our orders are going to be delivered within 12 weeks of order. So I would label them as short cycle. And Scott, don't predict or don't model another book-to-bill at 1.4 in the second quarter.

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes on the line of Nigel Coe with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes on the line of Nigel Coe with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to echo Scott's points about the year, strong start to the year there. So just semiconductor and North American gas, there is some concern about the second half maybe towards the back end of year, about those the two markets. First of all, wha
componenttext: Just wanted to echo Scott's points about the year, strong start to the year there. So just semiconductor and North American gas, there is some concern about the second half maybe towards the back end of year, about those the two markets. First of all, what is your view on that? And secondly, to what extent have you built that into your model?

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I guess we would fear those concerns, and I think we have built them into our model. If you look at our revised guidance on growth of the year, 7% to 10% organic, we have 7% in the first quarter. We've got an easier comp going into the second quarte
componenttext: Well, I guess we would fear those concerns, and I think we have built them into our model. If you look at our revised guidance on growth of the year, 7% to 10% organic, we have 7% in the first quarter. We've got an easier comp going into the second quarter, Nigel. But even with that, I will tell you that our organic growth forecast for the second quarter is mid-teens. We take that down significantly in the second half even though it's still favorable. We're looking at organic growth comparisons to the second half of last year of mid-single digits. So why? You've touched on the two whys, the Electronics business and our Energy business. With respect to Energy, the guys had a great start here to the year. We had a good first quarter. We're modeling that to essentially go sideways for the balance of the year. We take some of steam off the engine, so to speak, in Electronic Technologies in the second half. There is some seasonality that we expect to return to that business in the fourth quarter. I think we're recognizing that in our modeling.

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then the 15% margin, I mean that's up to your long-term margin goal. What does this tell us about the potential for long-term margins, 15% margins in the first quarter of a real recovery, where do you think margins can go longer term ?
componenttext: And then the 15% margin, I mean that's up to your long-term margin goal. What does this tell us about the potential for long-term margins, 15% margins in the first quarter of a real recovery, where do you think margins can go longer term ?

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, longer term, let's look at the next couple of years instead of the next seven. We were very pleased with the margin performance in the first quarter. And as I said in my prepared comments, I think it sets us up well to return to our peak margin perf
componenttext: Well, longer term, let's look at the next couple of years instead of the next seven. We were very pleased with the margin performance in the first quarter. And as I said in my prepared comments, I think it sets us up well to return to our peak margin performance, and we'll achieve that this year. It'll be between 15% to 16% operating margins. I think we do have some upside beyond that. It's something that we're discussing and looking at quite diligently across the businesses. But for modeling purposes, within a couple of years, I see us very capable of being at 17% margins or perhaps a bit better.

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010

componenttext: The backlog build at Hill PHOENIX was terrific. How much of that was due to some orders coming from Target? And how does that develop as it goes through the year because I'm assuming that, that could recur as we go through 2010?

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010
Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: And I'm not sure we've ever have had a book-to-bill at Hill PHOENIX in this level of nosebleed territory. I don't know what the percentage of our bookings were from Target. We were very pleased with the Target awards we had in the first quarter. They were
componenttext: And I'm not sure we've ever have had a book-to-bill at Hill PHOENIX in this level of nosebleed territory. I don't know what the percentage of our bookings were from Target. We were very pleased with the Target awards we had in the first quarter. They were higher than we had planned coming into the quarter. And we're expecting the guys to have a very, very strong second and third quarter as they satisfy the customers that have awarded us this business in the first quarter.

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of John Inch with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Bob, Dover was one of the most aggressive companies at taking out capacity and headcount in the downturn. And as we're rolling into some of these book-to-bill numbers in an accelerating economy for a lot of your businesses, how are you feeling about capac
componenttext: Bob, Dover was one of the most aggressive companies at taking out capacity and headcount in the downturn. And as we're rolling into some of these book-to-bill numbers in an accelerating economy for a lot of your businesses, how are you feeling about capacity generally within Dover? And just how does that dovetail with sort of your actions and just your ability to kind of, I think, satisfy demand in the near term? How should we be thinking about this, and how are you thinking about it?

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, there's two parts to the capacity response or response to the increasing orders. One is our workforce. The second part is our supply chain. And I think you can look at the data that's been shared here. Headcount was up in the first quarter. I think
componenttext: Well, there's two parts to the capacity response or response to the increasing orders. One is our workforce. The second part is our supply chain. And I think you can look at the data that's been shared here. Headcount was up in the first quarter. I think we added about 700 employees in the first quarter, John. Most of them, more than half of the employment increase in the first half was in Asia. So we're not reluctant to add employees and bring them back as the business conditions warrant or dictate. Supply chain is a bit of a different issue. We have seen it during the first quarter, and I expect we would continue to see it in the early part here in the second quarter. Some constraints on the supply chain, especially around the Electronics area. And the other parts of the business, I wouldn't label that as a significant concern.

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Bob, just talking about initiatives, could you just remind us where things stand on that point? Meaning maybe you can talk a little bit about supply rationalization. I mean the rate of recovery being so strong, has that put some of these activities on hol
componenttext: Bob, just talking about initiatives, could you just remind us where things stand on that point? Meaning maybe you can talk a little bit about supply rationalization. I mean the rate of recovery being so strong, has that put some of these activities on hold as you try and just manage for a recovery versus some of the pruning? And just maybe remind us what the cost benefits are this year to next year.

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me respond to the more general question, are we putting any of our activities on hold? And the answer is no, John. We still expect to end the year and go into 2011 with the same financial benefits that we gave you on our guidance call in January. And
componenttext: Let me respond to the more general question, are we putting any of our activities on hold? And the answer is no, John. We still expect to end the year and go into 2011 with the same financial benefits that we gave you on our guidance call in January. And the traction and the activity in that area remains very strong and very positive.

componenttextpreview: Alright. Well, you asked a question, but you make a statement. I don't think I said that it improved. I said it is still quite active. I wouldn't label the pipeline here today as much improved versus where it was 90 days ago. We have a lot of interesting
componenttext: Alright. Well, you asked a question, but you make a statement. I don't think I said that it improved. I said it is still quite active. I wouldn't label the pipeline here today as much improved versus where it was 90 days ago. We have a lot of interesting opportunities in our pipeline. And I think you should still expect that any acquisitions we do this year, view them to be strategic add-ons to existing, I call it, strong positions we have in our portfolio and small to mid-size type of acquisitions.

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010

componenttext: On price cost, you mentioned it a couple of times. And I guess in the Q, there was some commentary around the Refrigeration business and maybe a little bit in Energy. If you could just maybe talk about it, broadly what you're seeing across the portfolio on price cost and what you're assuming on raw materials in the back half of the year.

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me answer the question just overall for Dover. When we originally put out guidance back in January, we were assuming there was going to be some price-cost pressure. And at that time, we said it would be 60 to 75 basis points impact on margin. Today, w
componenttext: Let me answer the question just overall for Dover. When we originally put out guidance back in January, we were assuming there was going to be some price-cost pressure. And at that time, we said it would be 60 to 75 basis points impact on margin. Today, we see that as a little bit higher, let's say, we're estimating now in this guidance about 100 basis points, mostly all driven by commodities. Now I would then go one step further to say it's more prevalent in some of our businesses than others where we have a higher spend on commodities. But again, you're talking about a pretty small impact, mostly second-half weighted.

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think, Steve, perhaps the only other color I would add to that, if you look at our modeling and our revised guidance for the year, our first quarter gross margin was 38% plus a little bit. And we see us sustaining that for the balance of the year.
componenttext: I think, Steve, perhaps the only other color I would add to that, if you look at our modeling and our revised guidance for the year, our first quarter gross margin was 38% plus a little bit. And we see us sustaining that for the balance of the year.

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010

componenttext: And are there any particular areas where it's more acute? And can you just maybe talk about that in Refrigeration? But obviously, Hill PHOENIX is having a great start to the year, so maybe the volume just overwhelmed that, but any particular areas where you're seeing more?

componenttext: No. Actually, I'm not concerned about the gross margin and the commodity cost management at Hill PHOENIX. They do an outstanding job at that. I think the only thing that happened in the first quarter that probably cost us, I'm going to guess and say, maybe $0.01, Brad? Was the rapid increase in nickel in the first quarter. And we did feel that impact as well.

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010

componenttext: Yes, it was about $0.01.

componenttext: I think I'm doing a little bit of this as a recall, Rob. I don't have the data here in front of me. componenttext: I think we've clearly have seen that at the DEK business with respect to their traditional core printers. And one of the more interesting product launch successes we've had over the last 18 months was a product launch in the depths of the recession, in the first quarter of last year by DEK of a solar printing product offering that has shown very, very strong growth over the last 15 months. And order activity there was quite strong in the first quarter. And within the Test business, we've seen very strong order rates at Multitest in their first quarter and believe we're taking share there.

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Could you characterize your business geographically? Trends for other companies are stronger outside the U.S. and Europe than inside. So how's it going for you, and where can you capitalize on those geographic trends?
componenttext: Could you characterize your business geographically? Trends for other companies are stronger outside the U.S. and Europe than inside. So how's it going for you, and where can you capitalize on those geographic trends?

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me start first sort of the revenue split for the first quarter, and it's probably not much different than it was during most of last year. North America, and this is both the U.S. and Canada. So under North America, it was 60% of our revenue; Europe,
componenttext: Let me start first sort of the revenue split for the first quarter, and it's probably not much different than it was during most of last year. North America, and this is both the U.S. and Canada. So under North America, it was 60% of our revenue; Europe, about 18%; Asia, 14% to 15%; Latin America 4% to 5%; and I know I'm missing 2 or 3 points. Let's call it other. I think the second part was growth. Am I picking that up through, Alex?

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, yes. The other companies are saying that, that North American part and Western Europe is relatively weak. And the real strength is in Asia and Latin America.
componenttext: Well, yes. The other companies are saying that, that North American part and Western Europe is relatively weak. And the real strength is in Asia and Latin America.

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: The first quarter versus a year ago, North America growth was about 9%. Europe was about 8%. Latin America was about 40%, and Asia was about 55%. Of that huge number in Asia, 55%, it was 39% or 40% in China.
componenttext: The first quarter versus a year ago, North America growth was about 9%. Europe was about 8%. Latin America was about 40%, and Asia was about 55%. Of that huge number in Asia, 55%, it was 39% or 40% in China.

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: So what can you do now to capitalize on those kinds of trends going forward? I mean are you shifting some emphasis to those countries that are rapidly growing or are you leaving that up to individual units or what?
componenttext: So what can you do now to capitalize on those kinds of trends going forward? I mean are you shifting some emphasis to those countries that are rapidly growing or are you leaving that up to individual units or what?

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, both. And it's not something we're responding to this quarter. It's something we've been working on for the past 18 months. And again, not to overemphasize this, but it is a key part. It was the effort we made starting in the second half of '08 that
componenttext: Well, both. And it's not something we're responding to this quarter. It's something we've been working on for the past 18 months. And again, not to overemphasize this, but it is a key part. It was the effort we made starting in the second half of '08 that really did complete it last year was the establishment of our regional headquarters in China, which is providing a fair amount of infrastructure and assistance. And as we went through the downturn and did our restructuring in the first half of last year, we did as we closed some manufacturing facilities in North America and Europe. At the same time, we were bringing up some new facilities in Asia, in anticipation of the recovery of the economy. And we think it's benefited us. We'll continue to do that.

componenttext: Yes, but I guess where I was going with that specifically was given where U.S. natural gas prices are, I think I had heard you indicate in some of your colored commentary that you're assuming that, that business stays flat for the rest of the year. headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, I agree with that. In fact, when we look at our second quarter forecast and I will use the word "experts" in parenthesis, when we look at the expert forecast for the second quarter, rig count does start to moderate a little bit. Though from our viewpo
componenttext: No, I agree with that. In fact, when we look at our second quarter forecast and I will use the word "experts" in parenthesis, when we look at the expert forecast for the second quarter, rig count does start to moderate a little bit. Though from our viewpoint, the average rig count now in the second quarter forecast is about level with what the average was in the first quarter. But it is starting to decline. We see a real mix of forecast for the second half of the year with respect to rig count deployment. But we are assuming that, that activity is going to moderate a bit during the year...

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: So the rig count moderates, but your revenue stays stable. So you're gain in share. It's is not your customers who are pulling back on their drilling activity, is that the way to translate that?
componenttext: So the rig count moderates, but your revenue stays stable. So you're gain in share. It's is not your customers who are pulling back on their drilling activity, is that the way to translate that?

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, that's part of it. But you also have to appreciate that our entire Energy business is not directly correlated to rig count deployment. Obviously, our Sucker Rod business is pretty tightly correlated, as well as U.S. Synthetics. But U.S. Synthetics b
componenttext: Well, that's part of it. But you also have to appreciate that our entire Energy business is not directly correlated to rig count deployment. Obviously, our Sucker Rod business is pretty tightly correlated, as well as U.S. Synthetics. But U.S. Synthetics business is also quite international, so it is not quite as dependent on North American rig count activity as perhaps Norris sucker rods.

headline: Dover Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then coming back to the Electronic business, I wonder if you can talk about where you see inventories in the channel right now. I think across the tax base broadly, people are concerned about some double ordering that may have been going on. And where
componenttext: And then coming back to the Electronic business, I wonder if you can talk about where you see inventories in the channel right now.
