componenttextpreview: No, not really. I think it was really strictly related to our revenue number, which was obviously shipments.
componenttext: No, not really. I think it was really strictly related to our revenue number, which was obviously shipments.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just thinking about CapEx for 2011, it appears to us that CapEx growth shouldn't be in the double digits. You talked about this phenomenon of contractors ordering hydraulic shovels. Do you think as we roll over into 2011 that it will go toward yo
componenttext: And then just thinking about CapEx for 2011, it appears to us that CapEx growth shouldn't be in the double digits. You talked about this phenomenon of contractors ordering hydraulic shovels. Do you think as we roll over into 2011 that it will go toward your legacy business? Like, how long do we have to wait for your legacy surface mining business to pick up?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think we'll be fine. I just don't think it's going to be at significantly higher levels than what we've seen in '10. I think we thought that, that might be the case. We're going to see more of those legacy-type bookings, I think, in my opinion, towards
componenttext: I think we'll be fine. I just don't think it's going to be at significantly higher levels than what we've seen in '10. I think we thought that, that might be the case. We're going to see more of those legacy-type bookings, I think, in my opinion, towards around the middle part of '11. I think we're going to get out of the chute pretty quickly with probably more on the Terex product lines. Having said that, we have a lot of quotation activity on longwalls and electric mining shovels here in this quarter already. So it's going to be interesting to see how things do play out in the first half of 2011. As far as CapEx, for ourselves, we're running around $44 million at the end of September, and we're going to be ramping up some of that CapEx in 2011 to better serve some of the Terex products that are being sold right now.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Do you think that some of this delay as we go into booking legacy business has to do with the transition from brownfield to greenfield expansion? Is it just that it takes time for these greenfield expansions or for these customers to order the larger equi
componenttext: Do you think that some of this delay as we go into booking legacy business has to do with the transition from brownfield to greenfield expansion? Is it just that it takes time for these greenfield expansions or for these customers to order the larger equipment?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, partially, but there's also some of the things that we're looking at, our brownfield, for instance, in Australia and the Bowen basin. As mines keep going deeper, they will begin to look at longwalls for the longer term, and those are brownfield mines
componenttext: Yes, partially, but there's also some of the things that we're looking at, our brownfield, for instance, in Australia and the Bowen basin. As mines keep going deeper, they will begin to look at longwalls for the longer term, and those are brownfield mines. There are a couple of new mines in Australia coming on stream, but we're looking at some pretty good booking activity, we think, with some of our brownfield customers in the Bowen basin.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Steve Volkmann from Jefferies & Company.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Steve Volkmann from Jefferies & Company.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just to make sure I understand this right, I guess this revenue timing issue was that you were holding slots open that ultimately you didn't get the work done or were you actually doing some work that you weren't able to bill for?
componenttext: Just to make sure I understand this right, I guess this revenue timing issue was that you were holding slots open that ultimately you didn't get the work done or were you actually doing some work that you weren't able to bill for?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, it was all actually related to Reliance. We kept trying to move slots around in anticipation of the Exxon Bank financing we accrue. We slotted originally when we got the order back in November, which is typical for us. And then when they filed their E
componenttext: No, it was all actually related to Reliance. We kept trying to move slots around in anticipation of the Exxon Bank financing we accrue. We slotted originally when we got the order back in November, which is typical for us. And then when they filed their Exxon Bank application, we had really no idea that it was going to take literally almost 12 months to have that approved. So we kept moving the Reliance slots around in the schedule to the point that eventually, we had to take them out of the third quarter, and move them out into Q4, Q1, and that's effectively what created the hole in Q3.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Next question is I guess I was little surprised. Sequentially, it looked like the Terex margin was actually down slightly, and I may have my math wrong. But can you just sort of bring us up to speed on the cost savings and the margin of Terex and how that
componenttext: Next question is I guess I was little surprised. Sequentially, it looked like the Terex margin was actually down slightly, and I may have my math wrong. But can you just sort of bring us up to speed on the cost savings and the margin of Terex and how that's going to play out, and I guess with some focus on timing, if you can?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: We think we can improve the margins in the Terex product line commensurate, what we've been able to do on the underground and our historical heritage surface equipment. That's going to take us a while. Part of it's going to be in the plants. We're actuall
componenttext: We think we can improve the margins in the Terex product line commensurate, what we've been able to do on the underground and our historical heritage surface equipment. That's going to take us a while. Part of it's going to be in the plants. We're actually going to spend some money in some of the plants to make sure we can improve some of our cost basis and the three main plants that we do, and we actually just spend some money in our Denison drill plant. We were there yesterday, and it looks very, very good. So it's going to be a steady climb just like we did with the underground. Quarter-over-quarter, we hope to improve margins.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: So should we start to see that in the third and fourth quarter and sort of as we march into 2011?
componenttext: So should we start to see that in the third and fourth quarter and sort of as we march into 2011?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we hope to. I mean, that's our goal. So as we move quarter-to-quarter, we hope to improve that margin position.
componenttext: Yes, we hope to. I mean, that's our goal. So as we move quarter-to-quarter, we hope to improve that margin position.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Seth Weber from RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Seth Weber from RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Going back to the margin question, I mean, can you characterize what the pricing environment is like?  I mean, have there been any concessions as you guys have maybe started to bundle equipment together, or has the environment gotten any more competitive,
componenttext: Going back to the margin question, I mean, can you characterize what the pricing environment is like?  I mean, have there been any concessions as you guys have maybe started to bundle equipment together, or has the environment gotten any more competitive, either on the truck business or the shovel business?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: The answer to that is yes and yes. I think when we group equipment together, which we're happy to do and quite frankly, that's the whole purpose of the Terex acquisition. There is some discounting that's done to gather all that equipment together from the
componenttext: The answer to that is yes and yes. I think when we group equipment together, which we're happy to do and quite frankly, that's the whole purpose of the Terex acquisition. There is some discounting that's done to gather all that equipment together from the OE side. Obviously, the capital up front, and we expect to obviously reap the benefits of that with the balance from aftermarket. We're kind of the new player in the market, certainly on trucks. And we've been doing well on trucks out of the blocks, and the traditional players are certainly going to compete. So we'll see how it all plays out. I think there's room for everybody in this market, and I think over time that hopefully may temper, be tempered somewhat.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I mean, do you think it's on -- so the surface margin that you guys put up in the second quarter for the legacy BUCY business, do you think -- you're not going to revisit that kind of number again?
componenttext: I mean, do you think it's on -- so the surface margin that you guys put up in the second quarter for the legacy BUCY business, do you think -- you're not going to revisit that kind of number again?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Seth, this is Craig. We actually -- we're in right about 23%, 24% for the legacy business, which is a very good number for us. Our plan is to try and maintain that number as we go forward. As you recall in the second quarter, we've been a little bit highe
componenttext: Seth, this is Craig. We actually -- we're in right about 23%, 24% for the legacy business, which is a very good number for us. Our plan is to try and maintain that number as we go forward. As you recall in the second quarter, we've been a little bit higher than that, so our intent would be to try and maintain those margins as we go forward in 2011 based on the demand that we're seeing for the product.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just on the aftermarket, the weakness in the aftermarket, I mean, you cited the tough comparable with, I guess, the dragline activity in the year ago. Should we expect the aftermarket business to start to grow again here just on an organic basis?
componenttext: And then just on the aftermarket, the weakness in the aftermarket, I mean, you cited the tough comparable with, I guess, the dragline activity in the year ago. Should we expect the aftermarket business to start to grow again here just on an organic basis?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, yes. I think we can do, first and foremost, a better job on aftermarket with the Terex products. That's going to be a pickup. As you know, when you do a couple of dragline moves, those are big dollars, as Craig alluded to in his comments. And we jus
componenttext: Well, yes. I think we can do, first and foremost, a better job on aftermarket with the Terex products. That's going to be a pickup. As you know, when you do a couple of dragline moves, those are big dollars, as Craig alluded to in his comments. And we just have to make sure we highlight those. We have to highlight any maintenance and repair contracts that come in because those are the type of things that do have a fairly major impact on a quarterly basis for aftermarket. But overall, organically, we think we can do a much better job on aftermarket with some of the new products. And we think there's still a lot of opportunities out there for some of these dragline overhauls.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just lastly, Craig, did you say that there was a severance cost charge in the quarter of $2.4 million?
componenttext: And then just lastly, Craig, did you say that there was a severance cost charge in the quarter of $2.4 million?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, there was acquisition expenses related to Terex of approximately $0.5 million, and the difference would be some severance expenses that we've actually rationalized the three facilities around the world to try and have more efficient manufacturing oper
componenttext: No, there was acquisition expenses related to Terex of approximately $0.5 million, and the difference would be some severance expenses that we've actually rationalized the three facilities around the world to try and have more efficient manufacturing operations. So we had some severance related to those three closures.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, but that's not a specific call charge expense that gets split out anywhere, right?
componenttext: Okay, but that's not a specific call charge expense that gets split out anywhere, right?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, no. Let me explain -- no, it's just part of selling, general and admin expenses.
componenttext: No, no. Let me explain -- no, it's just part of selling, general and admin expenses.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Robert Wertheimer from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Robert Wertheimer from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: My first question is just on the order flow. Without trying to be insulting, I wonder if there's a little bit of where you may have missed on the older OE side of the surface because we're focused on Terex. I mean, did you reassign salespeople? Do they ch
componenttext: My first question is just on the order flow. Without trying to be insulting, I wonder if there's a little bit of where you may have missed on the older OE side of the surface because we're focused on Terex. I mean, did you reassign salespeople? Do they change incentives? Are they more focused on Terex in selling the other product by any chance?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, not at all. I think, if anything, those guys are still focused on both our legacy underground and surface products. And I think our market shares have been maintained on those products. So no, I think we're fine across the board.
componenttext: No, not at all. I think, if anything, those guys are still focused on both our legacy underground and surface products. And I think our market shares have been maintained on those products. So no, I think we're fine across the board.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Second question is just on the timing. I mean, I understand that there were some big CapEx announcements this year, and maybe that money was low to get spent and maybe, as you pointed out, some of it get spent on low risk contracting or whatever. I'm a li
componenttext: Second question is just on the timing. I mean, I understand that there were some big CapEx announcements this year, and maybe that money was low to get spent and maybe, as you pointed out, some of it get spent on low risk contracting or whatever. I'm a little confused as to why it might take all the way till middle part of next year to get going. I mean, are mines really still that hesitant? Is it just that slow to crank those dollars through the system or what?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, I think they're going to spend the money. I was trying to give some color as to where some of that money was going to be spent. I think that it's going to be spent more with some of the contractors out there, which will be our customers versus the big
componenttext: No, I think they're going to spend the money. I was trying to give some color as to where some of that money was going to be spent. I think that it's going to be spent more with some of the contractors out there, which will be our customers versus the big five. Those spend the CapEx, but it's going to go on a couple of different areas that aren't directly to us, but indirectly come to us. And I also think that we'll see how it plays out. I think they're right now trying to get those things lined up. That's what they've told us during the last two weeks. We want to make sure they get those contracts in place, and then they'll be talking to us about the capital they expect to spend with us.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Do you see a bifurcation next year in demand between underground and surface? Are you more confident in surface than underground? Are you seeing solid quarter in both?
componenttext: Do you see a bifurcation next year in demand between underground and surface? Are you more confident in surface than underground? Are you seeing solid quarter in both?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Solid quarter in both. I think, particularly, I think we're going to see probably a little bit above average longwall activity next year. As I mentioned, I think that we're looking at some of the mines in Queensland that are looking -- at going longwall t
componenttext: Solid quarter in both. I think, particularly, I think we're going to see probably a little bit above average longwall activity next year. As I mentioned, I think that we're looking at some of the mines in Queensland that are looking -- at going longwall that have traditionally not have longwalls installed in those mines. So I think across the board, we're looking at some pretty strong, both underground and surface activity next year.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jerry Revich from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jerry Revich from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Craig, looking at the guidance that you have for sales and EBITDA and are we seeing what that implies for the fourth quarter, I guess, if you take your numbers both sales and EBITDA, you get to 15% margins. You've been running closer to 19% year-to-date,
componenttext: Craig, looking at the guidance that you have for sales and EBITDA and are we seeing what that implies for the fourth quarter, I guess, if you take your numbers both sales and EBITDA, you get to 15% margins. You've been running closer to 19% year-to-date, can you just talk about whether you're expecting an adverse mix impact in the fourth quarter or is that just a situation where your profit execution has been better than you had expected year-to-date?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think it's a combination. We've given a range for the sales and the range for the earnings. So if you take maybe the low range of sales and the higher range of earnings. So it's a little difficult to predict exactly what the margin percent is going to b
componenttext: I think it's a combination. We've given a range for the sales and the range for the earnings. So if you take maybe the low range of sales and the higher range of earnings. So it's a little difficult to predict exactly what the margin percent is going to be in the quarter. But fundamentally, nothing's really changing from how we have been running the last couple of quarters. If anything, and our plan is to ramp up Terex with EBITDA margins over a three-year period to get them from where we started, up 13%, getting them up to 20% over that period. So as we go forward, we hope to see some incremental improvements on the Terex numbers going forward.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: And Craig, in that point, considering how strong orders have been in that part of the business, can you give us an update on facility optimization timing? Are we still thinking about moving to RH 400 in the second quarter drills in the first quarter? Is t
componenttext: And Craig, in that point, considering how strong orders have been in that part of the business, can you give us an update on facility optimization timing? Are we still thinking about moving to RH 400 in the second quarter drills in the first quarter? Is that still on track, or is that pushed out because of the strong shipments?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, those are still on track. As a matter fact, the Denison team is here this week already working on the transition of the large drills to Denison. And we've got our team on the ground from Milwaukee and Dortmund to move the RH 400s. So those are all sti
componenttext: No, those are still on track. As a matter fact, the Denison team is here this week already working on the transition of the large drills to Denison. And we've got our team on the ground from Milwaukee and Dortmund to move the RH 400s. So those are all still on track and exactly what we plan to do.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: And I recognize that you don't have a ton of visibility around your legacy surface orders and for a couple of quarters, it sounds like based on your comments. But overall, can you discuss directionally where you expect order trends for your overall busine
componenttext: And I recognize that you don't have a ton of visibility around your legacy surface orders and for a couple of quarters, it sounds like based on your comments. But overall, can you discuss directionally where you expect order trends for your overall business had to be at 2011 versus '10? And are we off base if we think that the total mining company CapEx budget's up 15%? So even if your mix of that changes a bit, your order should still be in a pretty good position year-on-year?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, now we're still bullish in '11 and '12 for sure. I think everyone needs to be cognizant of the fact that when these people announced what their CapEx budgets are. Those aren't all going to surface to underground equipment, but a good portion does. So
componenttext: Yes, now we're still bullish in '11 and '12 for sure. I think everyone needs to be cognizant of the fact that when these people announced what their CapEx budgets are. Those aren't all going to surface to underground equipment, but a good portion does. So I just want to make sure that you understand that and that there's a little different dynamic there. We'll get some of that CapEx indirectly as well.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: To continue, talk us through which regions contributed most of your new equipment orders this quarter, if you could touch on each segment? That would be helpful.
componenttext: To continue, talk us through which regions contributed most of your new equipment orders this quarter, if you could touch on each segment? That would be helpful.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, it was pretty much across-the-board. I think there wasn't any particular region that was unusually large. I think we had some reasonably good activity in Russia, Eastern Europe, Australia, South America, both at Chile and Peru, had some activity in
componenttext: Well, it was pretty much across-the-board. I think there wasn't any particular region that was unusually large. I think we had some reasonably good activity in Russia, Eastern Europe, Australia, South America, both at Chile and Peru, had some activity in Brazil, Southern Africa. We had some activity this quarter. It was no real large group of equipment from any particular sector. We actually even had a little bit of activity in China. So across the board this quarter.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: And, Tim, lastly, it's good to hear your comments about the Chinese competitive environment. Can you talk about how you're potentially thinking about deploying CapEx in that region, if at all?
componenttext: And, Tim, lastly, it's good to hear your comments about the Chinese competitive environment. Can you talk about how you're potentially thinking about deploying CapEx in that region, if at all?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: We are. I think we're actually expanding our Wang Thong operation, as we speak, and we're also looking at some other opportunities there for us, with some of our smaller equipment. We've had some good success with our underground diesel equipment. We're l
componenttext: We are. I think we're actually expanding our Wang Thong operation, as we speak, and we're also looking at some other opportunities there for us, with some of our smaller equipment. We've had some good success with our underground diesel equipment. We're looking to do some expansion there locally with that as well. So we're going to be very interested to see how this plays out with what the Chinese really plan to do with their policies on the coal industry. But we do have facilities there, and we do manufacture there, and we will continue to do that on a judicious basis.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Charlie Brady from BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Charlie Brady from BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just to clarify with the Reliance order, that obviously was not in Q3 bookings and will hit in Q4?
componenttext: Just to clarify with the Reliance order, that obviously was not in Q3 bookings and will hit in Q4?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's definitely Q4.
componenttext: That's definitely Q4.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can you quantify, is it $300 million or $400 million? There's been a few numbers that were thrown out there.
componenttext: Can you quantify, is it $300 million or $400 million? There's been a few numbers that were thrown out there.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's $310 million, to be precise.
componenttext: It's $310 million, to be precise.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, there's a press release, off by Exxon which is a higher number, but that would include other company besides ours that were part of that project. A portion of it is $310 million of that $900 million in the announcements.
componenttext: Yes, there's a press release, off by Exxon which is a higher number, but that would include other company besides ours that were part of that project. A portion of it is $310 million of that $900 million in the announcements.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: And that $900 million, I think, included the kind of an open line with this. It's still to be determined exactly what they're going to use it for.
componenttext: And that $900 million, I think, included the kind of an open line with this. It's still to be determined exactly what they're going to use it for.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Back on the Chinese comments, I mean, it certainly sounds as though your view on the Chinese market seems to me to me to be a bit more positive than you've been historically. I mean, have you had a rethink on your China policy and what the opportunity is
componenttext: Back on the Chinese comments, I mean, it certainly sounds as though your view on the Chinese market seems to me to me to be a bit more positive than you've been historically. I mean, have you had a rethink on your China policy and what the opportunity is there? It sounds like...

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I hope we're good listeners, let's put it that way. And I think over the last three or four years, the Chinese said, "We don't want to buy your equipment." If they are saying now that, "Well, maybe we're willing to do some more." And maybe because o
componenttext: Well, I hope we're good listeners, let's put it that way. And I think over the last three or four years, the Chinese said, "We don't want to buy your equipment." If they are saying now that, "Well, maybe we're willing to do some more." And maybe because of government pressure from the U.S. government, the protectionism they've had in the industry that they're willing to loosen it up a little bit, we obviously will react to that. And in some respects, we've already reacted to it by expanding our Wang Thong operations. So we're going to listen. And the good news about, I think, the Chinese is that when they say something, they effectively do it. I mean, they don't say something and give you a head fake and do something different. So we try to be good listeners, and if they do what they said they're going to do, we fully expect they will clearly, we'll react to that and modify our strategy accordingly.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Within the Australian market, are you seeing any commentary or pickup from your customers for gold mining? It seems that there was a lot more activity given what gold's got, and some of your strength, have you kind of trying to ramp up operations or expan
componenttext: Within the Australian market, are you seeing any commentary or pickup from your customers for gold mining? It seems that there was a lot more activity given what gold's got, and some of your strength, have you kind of trying to ramp up operations or expansion there?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, they have. And most of that gold is mined with smaller equipment, and that's what I would consider to be a new market for us. We have larger legacy-type equipment in some of the larger gold mines. But there's a lot of gold mines down there, Calguli [
componenttext: Yes, they have. And most of that gold is mined with smaller equipment, and that's what I would consider to be a new market for us. We have larger legacy-type equipment in some of the larger gold mines. But there's a lot of gold mines down there, Calguli [ph] in the southwestern part of Australia, which is really a Terex opportunity. So we're looking very, very carefully at that to see how we can participate there.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ann Duignan from JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ann Duignan from JPMorgan.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sorry to beat the dead horse, but I think you said last quarter that the Reliance order didn't get approved by the end of Q3, that it would cost you $70 million to $90 million in revenue. Should we for modeling standpoint put about $70 million to $90 mill
componenttext: Sorry to beat the dead horse, but I think you said last quarter that the Reliance order didn't get approved by the end of Q3, that it would cost you $70 million to $90 million in revenue. Should we for modeling standpoint put about $70 million to $90 million in revenue in Q4 and then the remainder in 2011? Is that the right way to think about it?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: We've lost part of that, obviously, because here, it came so late. I think -- what we're looking at Craig?
componenttext: We've lost part of that, obviously, because here, it came so late. I think -- what we're looking at Craig?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, that's about $50 million in the fourth quarter. So $50 million of our book to bill would be the Reliance order. The rest, we had to -- really, haven't started on the draglines yet.  I mean we hope to start by now, so that won't be probably until 201
componenttext: Well, that's about $50 million in the fourth quarter. So $50 million of our book to bill would be the Reliance order. The rest, we had to -- really, haven't started on the draglines yet.  I mean we hope to start by now, so that won't be probably until 2011 that we would on those, so we're down to about $50 million right now.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Could you talk a little bit since the Terex business is doing so well, can you talk about your Tier 4 Interim//Stage IIIB engine strategies? And what happens next year should that business doesn't become more competitively disadvantaged versus some of the
componenttext: Could you talk a little bit since the Terex business is doing so well, can you talk about your Tier 4 Interim//Stage IIIB engine strategies? And what happens next year should that business doesn't become more competitively disadvantaged versus some of the competitors?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think we're probably in the same boat as our competitors. Obviously, we're having discussions with all three supplies of engines to us, capped, commons and MTU [Maximum Transmission Unit]. We use all three supplies for excavators: diesel, drills and tru
componenttext: I think we're probably in the same boat as our competitors. Obviously, we're having discussions with all three supplies of engines to us, capped, commons and MTU [Maximum Transmission Unit]. We use all three supplies for excavators: diesel, drills and trucks. And really, since we don't manufacture engines, we rely on them to do what they're going to do with the Tier 4. But I think they're all kind of running at about the same pace. I think one or two of the suppliers maybe slightly ahead of their competition. But I think they're all kind of at the same place in Tier 4.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: And have you issued price increase notices to compensate for the increase in the cost of the engine?
componenttext: And have you issued price increase notices to compensate for the increase in the cost of the engine?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Where we have or where we've perceived that there might be cost increases, those will be baked into  our pricing, yes.
componenttext: Where we have or where we've perceived that there might be cost increases, those will be baked into  our pricing, yes.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: So we shouldn't see any negative impact on margins for Terex as a result of that?
componenttext: So we shouldn't see any negative impact on margins for Terex as a result of that?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, we're pretty good about keeping pace with our cost increases.
componenttext: No, we're pretty good about keeping pace with our cost increases.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: If I backout currency, your legacy business orders were down roughly 27% sequentially. I know you've talked about Australia and what's going on in that region. Is there anything else going on that we should be aware of that caused that significant decline
componenttext: If I backout currency, your legacy business orders were down roughly 27% sequentially. I know you've talked about Australia and what's going on in that region. Is there anything else going on that we should be aware of that caused that significant decline in currency adjusted orders, x Terex?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Not really, no.
componenttext: Not really, no.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: So it's just sit tight and wait, and the orders will re-accelerate?
componenttext: So it's just sit tight and wait, and the orders will re-accelerate?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's the timing that Tim was alluding to earlier that there's courting activity out there, but the customers are still haven't placed the orders yet, so let's wait for the timing as to when they think it's right for them.
componenttext: It's the timing that Tim was alluding to earlier that there's courting activity out there, but the customers are still haven't placed the orders yet, so let's wait for the timing as to when they think it's right for them.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Schon Williams from BB&T.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Schon Williams from BB&T.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's Schon Williams with BB&T. It looks like a number of your customers had some production issues in the third quarter. There were rains in Australia, the minors in the U.S. talking about some productivity issues given the regulatory environment. Did any
componenttext: It's Schon Williams with BB&T. It looks like a number of your customers had some production issues in the third quarter. There were rains in Australia, the minors in the U.S. talking about some productivity issues given the regulatory environment. Did any of that offset maybe the aftermarket orders in the quarter?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Not really. I think if anything, when we have disruptions like that, people spend on an aftermarket because they've got a window of opportunity to repair their machines. So no unusual activity, either way, on aftermarket during this period.
componenttext: Not really. I think if anything, when we have disruptions like that, people spend on an aftermarket because they've got a window of opportunity to repair their machines. So no unusual activity, either way, on aftermarket during this period.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wanted to maybe step back a little bit and talk about the industry a little bit. I mean, we've seen a lot talk of talk of consolidation by the miners.  I mean, it looks like Matsui [ph on the option block here. Can you talk about what consolidation mean
componenttext: I wanted to maybe step back a little bit and talk about the industry a little bit. I mean, we've seen a lot talk of talk of consolidation by the miners.  I mean, it looks like Matsui [ph on the option block here. Can you talk about what consolidation means for your business? Is that good, bad, neutral? What's your take there?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: We view consolidation as positive, particularly because of the portfolio of machines that we have right now. As producers get larger, they like to have large suppliers that can keep pace with their demands. So from our viewpoint, I think  consolidation is
componenttext: We view consolidation as positive, particularly because of the portfolio of machines that we have right now. As producers get larger, they like to have large suppliers that can keep pace with their demands. So from our viewpoint, I think  consolidation is fine. It's positive for us.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then last question on the balance sheet, it looks like long-term debt picked up a little bit in the quarter. Can you just talk about what your thoughts are in terms of paying down some of the Terex debt and kind of uses of cash going forward?
componenttext: And then last question on the balance sheet, it looks like long-term debt picked up a little bit in the quarter. Can you just talk about what your thoughts are in terms of paying down some of the Terex debt and kind of uses of cash going forward?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: There are debt [indiscernible] increased a little bit because of the exchange rates. We have part of our long-term debt denominated in euros, part of it is in Aussie dollars, so those currency that are a lot stronger that gives a little bit higher balance
componenttext: There are debt [indiscernible] increased a little bit because of the exchange rates. We have part of our long-term debt denominated in euros, part of it is in Aussie dollars, so those currency that are a lot stronger that gives a little bit higher balance on our balance sheet at the end of September. But right now, as you know, you saw our cash up to $350 million. We'll probably continue to monitor that for another quarter or two and decide, whether we want to start paying down some of the debt or continue to consider our alternatives. Our CapEx spending is going to increase, but not enough to make a significant difference in our decision. So we'll just accumulate the cash and see what opportunities present itself in the next couple of quarters, and at that point in time, we'll decide about paying down some of the debts.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: What about the dividend policy, has that changed at all? I mean dividend's, fairly, it's been flat essentially for the last several years. I mean, is there any thought there to changing that?
componenttext: What about the dividend policy, has that changed at all? I mean dividend's, fairly, it's been flat essentially for the last several years. I mean, is there any thought there to changing that?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: No. I think when we came out , we have, obviously, a very small dividend, and most of the investors that are on our stock today don't really pay too attention to it. We have literally no request on that. Most of the people are looking for growth, re-inves
componenttext: No. I think when we came out , we have, obviously, a very small dividend, and most of the investors that are on our stock today don't really pay too attention to it. We have literally no request on that. Most of the people are looking for growth, re-investment of the capital back in the business. That's what we're doing.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Tim, can you talk to your current capacity utilization in the Truck business? Terex, of course, wasn't known for foreign capital into that business, And I'm wondering how long you can maintain an availability advantage over, say, CAT?
componenttext: Tim, can you talk to your current capacity utilization in the Truck business? Terex, of course, wasn't known for foreign capital into that business, And I'm wondering how long you can maintain an availability advantage over, say, CAT?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, obviously, CAT's a much larger producer of trucks than we are, but I think we can have a meaningful market share, and that's going to require, once we max out the number of units that we're capable of building, we're going to have to spend some mone
componenttext: Well, obviously, CAT's a much larger producer of trucks than we are, but I think we can have a meaningful market share, and that's going to require, once we max out the number of units that we're capable of building, we're going to have to spend some money. We're looking at probably getting to that max number next year, which means that we are going to have to look at spending some capital probably a bit next year to determine what we really want to do with that product line.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010

componenttext: Can you give us an idea of how far above where we are now that cap is?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we think we can probably build up to 150 to 170 trucks a year, in that visibility. And obviously, that's woefully inadequate for what we think we can do as far as placing trucks. The good news is we've got plenty of land and plenty of ability to not
componenttext: Well, we think we can probably build up to 150 to 170 trucks a year, in that visibility. And obviously, that's woefully inadequate for what we think we can do as far as placing trucks. The good news is we've got plenty of land and plenty of ability to not spend a huge amount of capital to increase that capacity. Now we've built these trucks in a Acuna, Mexico, and we've got a lot of land, a lot of capability down there. So we're looking at that very carefully. We really want to get to that high-end next year as far as numbers of units, if we can, and then look at expansion.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010

componenttext: Your run rate now is, I mean, do you mind?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's low. I think we're about half of our capacity for 2010 right now. I think part of that was when we bought the company in February was the plant was effectively empty. They are not really been out pushing product. That's changed dramatically here, obv
componenttext: It's low. I think we're about half of our capacity for 2010 right now. I think part of that was when we bought the company in February was the plant was effectively empty. They are not really been out pushing product. That's changed dramatically here, obviously, in the last two quarters, and we expect it to continue to improve. So we started from zero effectively, and I think the guys have done a nice job getting a part from the production schedule for the second half of the year. And I think a part of the other problem, Rob, is there's a different philosophy there. I mean, they would make trucks to order only. You can't do that. You've got to anticipate what the market needs are and build and load that plant. And that's what we do on our other businesses, and that's what we're going to do on trucks.

componenttext: Can you clarify what you meant by being able to deliver the fourth quarter, assuming $250 million of incremental orders shippable in the quarter? Are we talking about needing to take the current run rate of order activity and add $250 million to it? I mean, that's a lot, isn't it?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Not really. I mean, part of that, we just told, we've got $50 million already, and that's the book to bill on the Reliance order. We've got some other things on aftermarket that are just -- they happen. And we think the $250 million, the $250 million is n
componenttext: Not really. I mean, part of that, we just told, we've got $50 million already, and that's the book to bill on the Reliance order. We've got some other things on aftermarket that are just -- they happen. And we think the $250 million, the $250 million is not the issue. I think we feel pretty comfortable about that. The real issue is these guys have got a lot of work to do this quarter because things, as you know, with our growth pattern get back-end loaded. well, we're really back-end loaded this year, and all the plants are going to have to perform here in the fourth quarter, and I think they're up to it.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I have a question regarding your order rates. We've seen the order rates improve. And if I go back first quarter '08, you had almost $1.1 billion in orders, and that was the underground and legacy surface. You've almost hit about $1.1 billion again in the
componenttext: I have a question regarding your order rates. We've seen the order rates improve. And if I go back first quarter '08, you had almost $1.1 billion in orders, and that was the underground and legacy surface. You've almost hit about $1.1 billion again in the second quarter. You have that $1 billion plus run rate. Legacy is a little bit weak, Terex is kicking in. If CapEx is up and quotation activity is high and we start trending to $1.2 billion, $1.3 billion in orders a quarter, how are you going to be able to handle that on the capacity side? What sort of investments have you made? What's your capacity on the shovel side, and how quickly can you convert these incoming orders in the calendar year or over 12 months?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think in every product line, every facility is different. We are expanding our LÃ¼nen operations. We are expanding our Wang Thong operations because of the fact that we think we've got this longwall activity that's coming up that we need more capacity.
componenttext: I think in every product line, every facility is different. We are expanding our LÃ¼nen operations. We are expanding our Wang Thong operations because of the fact that we think we've got this longwall activity that's coming up that we need more capacity. Our Milwaukee operations has plenty of capacity. That's why we're removing the RH-400 here to loosen up some capacity endorsement for our other hydroelectric excavators. We're increasing our capacity in Denison by 50%. We're not increasing our capacity right now in Acunia. But as I just mentioned to the last caller, that's a probability here as we move into 2011. We're going to need more capacity there. So we're already reacting to where we think the market's going to take us and where we have capacity. We're shifting some things around. So we're trying to stay ahead of the game.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, that was a very successful introduction and I think it opened a lot of eyes to what is out there in the marketplace internationally. The domestic market is very soft right now. And having said that, I think there is some wait-and-see type at
componenttext: Yes, I think, that was a very successful introduction and I think it opened a lot of eyes to what is out there in the marketplace internationally. The domestic market is very soft right now. And having said that, I think there is some wait-and-see type attitude. But we really feel that the plow systems have a place in central Appalachia. And I think if coking coal prices stay firm and if we get some recovery on steam coal here, that we'll see some nice activity for those systems, particularly in the Eastern U.S.

componenttext: Just two like kind of structural questions, one on the Terex mix. It's a little bit weaker, as you said, and there's a lot of demand coming in that product line. So when you look at the margins in 2011 and 2012, is there enough improvement coming from the Terex side and from the legacy Bucyrus as well as incremental volume that the margins can continue to make progress or can you give us a sense?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we can. Some of that's going to come from operational improvements. I'm not sure it's going to come from the pricing side. As we talked about earlier in the call, I think it's competitive out there right now. But I think we can pick up margin
componenttext: Yes, I think we can. Some of that's going to come from operational improvements. I'm not sure it's going to come from the pricing side. As we talked about earlier in the call, I think it's competitive out there right now. But I think we can pick up margin just on some of our plant efficiencies and what we're doing. We've seen it already. I think you've seen some of that in this quarter, and I think we'll continue to see that as we move through '11 and '12.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then also sort of structure on the industry. The flow of business seems like it ought to be -- you have pretty good visibility, right, with new mines come on, and they're finished and all that. So are we going to see more of the volatility around the
componenttext: And then also sort of structure on the industry. The flow of business seems like it ought to be -- you have pretty good visibility, right, with new mines come on, and they're finished and all that. So are we going to see more of the volatility around the quarter-to-quarter, or do you think there's enough uncertainty out there in the market on capital spending and things like that, that it might be longer than that? You know what I mean, not the short, choppy, it could be sort of longer -- I don't know, whatever, like dips in business and then surges, you know what I'm saying?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think I know what you're saying. I'm more on the longer-term type of mentality on that, I think, or mind. It's interesting where its almost like we're one kind of dips, something else picks up the pace. You've got enough markets out there that have
componenttext: Yes, I think I know what you're saying. I'm more on the longer-term type of mentality on that, I think, or mind. It's interesting where its almost like we're one kind of dips, something else picks up the pace. You've got enough markets out there that have -- there's enough commodities now that we're involved in that where one falters or pulls back a little bit, you got someone else picking it up. So I think if you buy into the macro view on where we're at from the commodity spend, it's going to be choppy in certain markets. It's going to be some choppy with certain products from time to time. But the overall trend is upward, and I think that's the good news of the market we're in right now.

componenttext: Thank you. Well, it was an interesting quarter, to say the least. I think the challenge that we did have on the revenue side, I think our guys did a great job working with the new customer with some real difficult third-party type issues. I would like to thank the members and the staff of U.S. Exxon. They really worked through some tough situations, and they were with us the whole way, trying to work us through this whole situation on the size of the project, and I'm particularly grateful for their efforts. They've put a lot of work into this to get us across the finish line. I think we're looking for a good fourth quarter. We're hitting it hard, and I think that we'll have some good news, come February. Thanks for joining the call again today, and as always, call us whenever you have any questions, and we'll talk to you again in February.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Third Quarter 2010 Dover Corporation Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to Mr. Paul Goldberg, Treasurer and Director of Investor Relations of Dover Corporation. Mr. Gol
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to the Third Quarter 2010 Dover Corporation Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to Mr. Paul Goldberg, Treasurer and Director of Investor Relations of Dover Corporation. Mr. Goldberg, please go ahead, sir.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jackie. Good morning, and welcome to Dover's Third Quarter Earnings Call. With me today are Bob Livingston, Dover's President and Chief Executive Officer; Brad Cerepak, our CFO; and Dave Van Loan. Dave is President of our Electronic Technologie
componenttext:
Thank you, Jackie. Good morning, and welcome to Dover's Third Quarter Earnings Call. With me today are Bob Livingston, Dover's President and Chief Executive Officer; Brad Cerepak, our CFO; and Dave Van Loan. Dave is President of our Electronic Technologies segment. 
Today's call will begin with comments from Bob and Brad on Dover's third quarter operating and financial performance and our updated outlook for the rest of 2010. We will then open the call up to questions. [Operator Instructions] Please note that our current earnings release, investor supplement and associated presentation can be found on our website, www.dovercorporation.com. This call will be available for playback through November 5, and the audio portion of this call will be archived on our website for three months. The replay telephone number is 1 (800) 642-1687. When accessing the playback, you'll need to supply the following reservation code, 14334215.
Before we get started, I'd like to remind everyone that our comments today, which are intended to supplement your understanding of Dover, may contain certain forward-looking statements that are inherently subject to uncertainties. We caution everyone to be guided in their analysis of Dover Corporation by referring to our Form 10-K for a list of factors that could cause our results to differ from those anticipated in any such forward-looking statement. Also we undertake no obligation to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statements except as required by law. We would also direct your attention to our website where considerably more information can be found.
And with that, I'd like to turn this call over to Bob.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Paul. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us for this morning's conference call. I'm happy to have Dave Van Loan join us today to participate in the Q&A portion of this call. And offer his keen insight on one of our many success stories
componenttext:
Thanks, Paul. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us for this morning's conference call. I'm happy to have Dave Van Loan join us today to participate in the Q&A portion of this call. And offer his keen insight on one of our many success stories this year, the growth in Electronic Technologies.
I am pleased to report Dover saw a strong third quarter gains in revenue, bookings, earnings and margin, reflecting very solid performance across the majority of our companies and the continuing benefits of our productivity initiatives. Orders were up 27% and revenue increased 26%, reflecting the steady improvement in the majority of our end markets. Organic revenue growth was 25%, acquisitions contributed 3%, FX had a negative impact of 2%.
In the third quarter, we saw a continuation of several positive trends that had been prevalent throughout the year. Knowles continued to benefit from the growing handset market, especially the growth in smartphones. DEK is enjoying a strong recovery in the electronic assembly market and increasing demand for their product innovations and solar equipment. U.S. Synthetic has shown tremendous growth driven by the strong rebound in North America rig count, increases in horizontal drilling and share gains. Our Pump Solutions group has seen a steady increase in their business, notably in Asia. This growth in Asia is also evident in our Vehicle Service group, which has seen a nice jump in their activity connected to the China auto market. Lastly, the seasonal ramp up at Hill PHOENIX was even stronger than expected at the beginning of the quarter, largely driven by remodel activity and taking advantage of the recent capacity expansion in our Richmond facility.
Now let's move to our third quarter results and Brad will discuss our guidance later in the call. Today, we reported third quarter revenue of $1.9 billion, an increase of 26% over last year. Earnings per share from continuing operations increased 103% to $1.18, including tax benefits of $0.20. Adjusted EPS was $0.98, a 69% improvement over last year. On a sequential basis, revenue and adjusted EPS increased 6% and 8%, respectively. Bookings increased 27% over last year to $1.8 billion. Book-to-bill finished at 0.96. 
Segment operating margin for the quarter was 17.1%, up 280 basis points. Year-over-year margins increased significantly at Fluid Management, Electronic Technologies and Industrial Products, while Engineered Systems margin remained strong. This quarterly segment margin result is the highest in recent memory.
In the third quarter, we generated free cash flow of $157 million, 8% of revenue, reflecting an increase in working capital to support our expanding businesses and continued CapEx investments to support our future growth expectations. We are still targeting full year free cash flow to be around 10% of revenue.
Our acquisition pipeline continues to be full and has matured nicely. We closed on three small deals totaling $35 million during the quarter. We have several targets in our five growth spaces and fully expect to close some transactions in the next few months.
I'm quite pleased with our strong performance in the third quarter, especially with regard to revenue growth and operating margin. Our results reflect our company's continued focus on their customers, our cost base and productivity. Our third quarter order rates and backlog have us well-positioned as we start the fourth quarter. 
With that, let me turn it over to Brad, for comments on our segment performance.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bob. Good morning, everyone. Let's start by turning to Slide 5. As Bob mentioned, sequential revenue increased 6%, reflecting growth across all our segments and platforms. Sequential revenue growth was 10% in Electronic Technologies; 7%,  in Engin
componenttext:
Thanks, Bob. Good morning, everyone. Let's start by turning to Slide 5. As Bob mentioned, sequential revenue increased 6%, reflecting growth across all our segments and platforms. Sequential revenue growth was 10% in Electronic Technologies; 7%,  in Engineered Systems, and we saw more modest growth in Fluid Management and Industrial Products. 
On a sequential basis, bookings declined 6% in the quarter, principally reflecting normal seasonality. The sequential decline in engineered products, consistent with last year's experience, was largely attributable to Hill PHOENIX. 
In addition, mobile equipment was impacted by a military order booked in the second quarter, which amplified the modest seasonality normally seen in this platform. 
With respect to geographic growth, Latin America was our fastest growing region in the third quarter with a growth rate of 48%, Asia grew 41%, North America grew at 26%, while Europe was up 19%. Our companies remain focused on growing their businesses in the Asian and Latin American markets. Also of note, the third quarter marks the first time our Asian revenue exceeded Europe's revenue in absolute dollar terms.
Turning to Slide 6. Industrial products posted revenue of $471 million and $59 million of earnings, an increase of 19% and 56%, respectively. This strong earnings performance was a result of increased volume across Material Handling, productivity and leverage on a lower cost base. 
Bookings were $456 million, an increase of 29%, reflecting broad-based year-over-year improvement. Sequentially, bookings were down 11%, resulting in a book-to-bill of 0.97. 
Industrial Products quarterly operating margin was 12.6%, up 300 basis points from last year and 20 basis points sequentially, adjusting for a one-time gain in the second quarter. Again, our earlier rightsizing actions continue to put this segment in a strong position to leverage any further increases in demand. 
With respect to our Material Handling platform, sales increased 43% to $221 million. Earnings nearly tripled, driven by increased activity across most end markets, as each operating company delivered double-digit revenue growth. In total, Material Handling margins were up 760 basis points, reflecting strong conversion on volume.
For the quarter, bookings were $223 million, an increase of 37% over last year and flat sequentially, yielding a book-to-bill of 1.01. North American residential construction trends continue to show modest improvement.
With respect to our Mobile Equipment platform, sales were $251 million, up 4% from last year, and earnings were essentially flat. Margins decreased 50 basis points, primarily reflecting product mix. Though sequential bookings declined 6% after adjusting for a large Q2 military order, they increased 22% year-over-year to $234 million. This improvement was driven by international growth at Vehicle Services Group and the beginnings of a recovery in selected trailer markets. Book-to-bill finished at 0.93.
Turning to Slide 7. At Engineered Systems, we posted record quarterly revenue and earnings. Sales were $620 million, an increase of 19%, and segment earnings increased 17% to $91 million. The year-over-year growth in revenue is largely attributable to strong performances at Hill PHOENIX and Belvac. For the quarter, operating margin was 14.7%, a 30 basis point decline from last year and flat, sequentially. Bookings were $547 million, an increase of 16% over the prior year.
On a sequential basis, bookings reflected the normal seasonal patterns and were down 9% resulting in a book-to-bill of 0.88.
Our Product Identification platform continue to benefit from strong demand in developing economies. Third quarter sales were $222 million, an increase of 5%, which included a negative FX impact of 2%. Year-over-year earnings were flat, and margins decreased 90 basis points. Margin performance was impacted by increased investment in R&D and business development activities in emerging markets and revenue mix. Book-to-bill was 0.98.
Moving to Engineered Products. Third quarter sales were $399 million, an increase in revenue of 29% with acquisitions accounting for 8% of the growth. Earnings increased 33%, resulting in margin expansion of 40 basis points over last year and 10 basis points, sequentially. Favorable margin performance was largely driven by volume improvements, which were partially offset by product and customer mix and continued price material cost spread at SWEP. Engineered products bookings were $329 million, an increase of 27% over the prior year, primarily driven by Hill PHOENIX and aided by the Barker acquisition of last year. Sequential bookings declined 13% in the third quarter, resulting in a book-to-bill of 0.83. This result reflects normal seasonal order patterns at Hill PHOENIX.
Now moving to Slide 8. At Fluid Management, revenue increased 35% to $416 million, while earnings increased 68% to $102 million. Third quarter operating margin was 24.5%, a 490 basis point expansion over last year and an increase of 70 basis points, sequentially. Bookings were $409 million, an increase of 26% over the prior year, resulting in a book-to-bill of 0.98. 
With respect to our Energy platform, revenue increased 52% to $220 million while earnings increased 80%. Margin improved 480 basis points on significantly higher volume, driven by an expanding North American rig count, including an increase in horizontal drilling and productivity gains. Quarterly bookings increased 35% to $213 million, but declined 6% sequentially off an extremely strong second quarter. Book-to-bill was 0.97. The end markets in this platform remain healthy and our businesses are well-positioned. Looking forward in Q4, we anticipate North American rig count to be modestly positive.
Moving to Fluid Solutions. This platform generated revenue of $197 million, an increase of 19%. Earnings increased 45%, resulting in 390 basis point margin improvement, a tremendous performance. Bookings increased 18% year-over-year to $196 million, and book-to-bill remained steady at one. We are seeing a continuation of modest improvement in most of this platform-served markets and our Pump group continues to make great inroads in developing regions, especially Asia.
Turning to Slide 9. Electronic Technologies revenue was $381 million, an increase of 39%. The majority of end markets in this segment were up significantly year-over-year with continuing strong demand for electronic assembly equipments, MEMS microphones, Passive Components and our emerging solar products. Earnings were $70 million, an 82% improvement over last year. Operating margin was 18.3%, driven by significantly higher volume and strong conversion on an improved cost base. Bookings were $402 million, up 42% over last year. Book-to-bill continues to be solid at 1.05.
Our electronic assembly equipment companies posted a 65% jump in revenue year-over-year, and continue to see improving order book for the sixth consecutive quarter. Book-to-bill was 1.14. Although we anticipate some normal seasonal softness in the fourth quarter, we expect the climate in the electronic assembly markets to remain positive.
Lastly, our communication components companies posted another solid quarter, reflecting continued strength at Knowles, CMP and Vectron. We ended the quarter with a book-to-bill of one, although we did see some moderation in the telecom infrastructure markets as we enter the fourth quarter.
Having reviewed the segments, I'd now would like to briefly provide some additional financial data. 
Moving to Slide 10. Second quarter net interest expense was $26 million, flat with last year and in line with our full year guidance. Our net debt to total capitalization was 14.8%, down 360 basis points from year end, largely reflecting higher cash balances and lower debt. 
With respect to taxes, our third quarter tax rate was largely impacted by U.S. tax settlements and the resolution of a foreign tax position, resulting in a benefit of $0.20 EPS in the quarter. This is comprised of two elements: $0.15 EPS related to a discreet tax settlement in the quarter; and $0.05 EPS related to the reduction of the annual effective tax rate. We now expect the annual full year tax rate, inclusive of the previously mentioned $0.20 of tax benefits to be about 25.5%. Corporate expenses were up slightly from last year and were impacted by a one-time $4.3 million charge associated with the early extinguishment of debt.
Turning to Slide 11. As discussed, third quarter revenue and bookings were strong for us across Dover. We now expect full year revenue growth, including acquisitions, to be in the range of 20% to 21%. Here's the breakdown by segment of our revenue growth: we expect that Industrial Products revenue should grow 11% to 12%; Engineered Systems revenue should increase 17% to 18%, including acquisition growth of 9%; Fluid Management revenue growth should be in the range of 25% to 26%, including 3% from acquisitions; lastly, Electronic Technologies should sharply grow revenue at the mid-30% level, with no material impact from acquisitions.
Now let's go to the full year earnings bridge on Slide 12. Volume remains the biggest driver of the increase in earnings. Volume, product mix and pricing should improve earnings $1.11 to $1.20 while restructuring and productivity will have a continuing impact as well. Our acquisitions continue to perform at a high level and will now deliver $0.13 for the year. Corporate expense is roughly in line with previous estimates. Compensation expense is a function of our improved revenue and earnings forecast. 
Lastly, tax significantly increases our revised forecast. We add $0.20 to our forecast to reflect discreet tax benefits in the quarter. And the impact of the reduction of the annual effective rate. As a result, we are now increasing our full year EPS guidance and expect to be in the range of $3.50 to $3.55. 
Now I'd like to turn the call back over to Bob.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Brad. We've had three great quarters and fully expect to finish the year in good form. In addition, we've made great progress in further establishing a foundation for growth. Throughout the year, we've made investments in product innovation, capac
componenttext:
Thanks, Brad. We've had three great quarters and fully expect to finish the year in good form. In addition, we've made great progress in further establishing a foundation for growth. Throughout the year, we've made investments in product innovation, capacity, supply chains, people and geographic expansion. We focused on our five growth spaces: Refrigeration and Food Equipment, Fluid Solutions, Energy, Product ID and Communication Components. We believe these spaces offer us the greatest opportunity to grow, both organically and through acquisitions. 
Lastly, the opportunities for growth in developing economies are significant for Dover. As Brad mentioned earlier, third quarter revenue in Asia was larger than in Europe. I would expect this trend to continue. I am excited with our growth's prospects, and look forward to sharing our outlook with you at our Investor Day in New York on November 15. And in closing, I'd like to personally thank everyone at Dover for all their efforts and contributions to a very positive third quarter. 
With that, back to Paul.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bob. At this point, I'd just like to remind everybody again, if you can limit yourself to one question with a follow-up, we'll be better positioned to answer everybody's questions. And with that, I'd like to turn it over to Jackie.
componenttext:
Thanks, Bob. At this point, I'd just like to remind everybody again, if you can limit yourself to one question with a follow-up, we'll be better positioned to answer everybody's questions. 
And with that, I'd like to turn it over to Jackie.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
