componenttext: You're looking at the earnings bridge? That tax line, there's two tax lines there. One is for the discrete $0.20 that we spoke about, the other line really is just a comparison of tax year-over-year, but nothing unusual in there. But you do recall, we did have a discrete item in last year's second quarter. So that's part of what you see in that second line.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Scott Davis with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Scott Davis with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: When you look at the just phenomenal growth you've had in Electronic Tech, it begs kind of the question and particularly in MEMS microphones, where are you in relation to kind of capacity? And at what point do you need to add capacity or how kind of scala
componenttext: When you look at the just phenomenal growth you've had in Electronic Tech, it begs kind of the question and particularly in MEMS microphones, where are you in relation to kind of capacity? And at what point do you need to add capacity or how kind of scalable is your production? And the following question to that is really what are your competitors doing? And I know you have very large shares and such, but often times, when you have growth rates like this, often times you have a more aggressive competitive response. So maybe you could address both of those issues?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Scott, was your question all around MEMS? We understood the first part, the second part about competitors, were you referring to MEMS?
componenttext: Scott, was your question all around MEMS? We understood the first part, the second part about competitors, were you referring to MEMS?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, you could broaden it out. I mean I was speaking to -- I mean, thinking in terms of kind of example being MEMS, but you could speak to the whole segment if you'd like.
componenttext: Yes, you could broaden it out. I mean I was speaking to -- I mean, thinking in terms of kind of example being MEMS, but you could speak to the whole segment if you'd like.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'll kick it off, Dave's chomping at the bit here to jump in with a quick response. But if you look at the MEMS business, we've owned Knowles now for five years and a month. I don't think there's been a year since they've been part of Dover that we haven'
componenttext: I'll kick it off, Dave's chomping at the bit here to jump in with a quick response. But if you look at the MEMS business, we've owned Knowles now for five years and a month. I don't think there's been a year since they've been part of Dover that we haven't had capacity addition projects. We did it in '09 during the downturn. We've got additional capacity adding projects underway for '10 that could come online or they should come online by the end of the first quarter going into the second quarter of next year. And if you look at our long-term planning, we expect additional projects to fund next year. To give you a magnitude, this year, our capacity add projects at Knowles will be about a $20 million investment. We are trying to not only support the growth at Knowles, but trying to stay in front of the growth with enough capacity adds that we don't constrain our delivery or disrupt our customers. With that, Dave can probably add a little bit more color.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Scott, your question about the competition, it might surprise you, when we look at our competition in this business, we're really looking more at our traditional ECM microphone competitors than alternative suppliers in the MEMS microphone business. So the
componenttext: Scott, your question about the competition, it might surprise you, when we look at our competition in this business, we're really looking more at our traditional ECM microphone competitors than alternative suppliers in the MEMS microphone business. So there are a number of cellphones out there today that are still using ECM mics. We look at that as a great opportunity. This is a growth opportunity for us to convert these customers to MEMS technology, which has a tremendous number of advantages in that area. On the competitors in the MEMS side of the business, strangely enough, that's actually, we look at that as a good thing. We don't see anybody with huge capacity or huge wins out there today. But having that second source for our customers actually helps us in our quest to bring more of the ECM customers across as they have a second source.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Am I to assume that the $20 million investment is pretty much all entirely China?
componenttext: Am I to assume that the $20 million investment is pretty much all entirely China?

componenttextpreview: Asia.
componenttext: Asia.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010

componenttext: It's outside of China, too?

componenttextpreview: Yes. We've got facilities in Malaysia as well.
componenttext: Yes. We've got facilities in Malaysia as well.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: You had a pretty dramatic ramp at Knowles this year. What was that business up in the quarter?
componenttext: You had a pretty dramatic ramp at Knowles this year. What was that business up in the quarter?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't have that data in front of me. Do you want to take a guess at that response? The revenue third quarter increased, maybe a little bit better than 20%.
componenttext: I don't have that data in front of me. Do you want to take a guess at that response? The revenue third quarter increased, maybe a little bit better than 20%.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: So actually less than the segment increase?
componenttext: So actually less than the segment increase?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: For sure. You look at the growth and Dave can give you some color on this, but you look at the growth in not just the third quarter, but the second quarter on the organic growth rates. The comps were extremely favorable for the equipment companies. They'v
componenttext: For sure. You look at the growth and Dave can give you some color on this, but you look at the growth in not just the third quarter, but the second quarter on the organic growth rates. The comps were extremely favorable for the equipment companies. They've not only had a great year this year, but as we all know, they really struggled with the downturn in the first half of '09. Interestingly, Steve, we did not see the decline even though we saw some decline, we did not see the sharpness in decline in our Communication Components business in 2009 like we saw in our equipment businesses.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: So does that business -- the Component business was up solidly, but not as much as the segment. And next year, are there any dynamics around timing of platform ramps or anything like that, that would lead to anything but kind of a normal year at those Com
componenttext: So does that business -- the Component business was up solidly, but not as much as the segment. And next year, are there any dynamics around timing of platform ramps or anything like that, that would lead to anything but kind of a normal year at those Components businesses, including Knowles?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the Knowles business, Steve, is we're looking at the opportunity for one of our major customers, who've recently announced the partnering with a release for Verizon. This is obviously Apple, and we see this as a real opportunity for our business to
componenttext: Well, the Knowles business, Steve, is we're looking at the opportunity for one of our major customers, who've recently announced the partnering with a release for Verizon. This is obviously Apple, and we see this as a real opportunity for our business to take off in that area. When we look at some of these high-end cellphones or high-end smartphones, it's not just a matter of a single microphone anymore. We actually have applications today where we've got two mics in place for active noise cancellation and the third mic used for voice activation on the phone. So these are very dramatic markets. The share back-and-forth between our various customers is a very positive opportunity for us, and the multiple mic phenomena just continues to gain traction.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: So does that business actually accelerate next year from a revenue growth perspective?
componenttext: So does that business actually accelerate next year from a revenue growth perspective?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll see.
componenttext: We'll see.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: We certainly are very, very optimistic about that market in that space.
componenttext: We certainly are very, very optimistic about that market in that space.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: And just to be clear, you guys are seeing no weakness in the Equipment side of things? Any push outs or anything like that on the equipment side?
componenttext: And just to be clear, you guys are seeing no weakness in the Equipment side of things? Any push outs or anything like that on the equipment side?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: We've seen no push outs at all. We have a very solid backlog for the fourth quarter, and we expect to finish the good performance we've had this year. We expect that to continue and to finish on in very good form.
componenttext: We've seen no push outs at all. We have a very solid backlog for the fourth quarter, and we expect to finish the good performance we've had this year. We expect that to continue and to finish on in very good form.

componenttext: One of your competitors in display cases, I'm not sure, if you've already gone through this and just tell me and I'll just read the transcript. But your key competitor on the display case side reported bookings up 20% this quarter. You guys are talking about kind of normal seasonality, Hill PHOENIX, maybe that's just timing of orders or something. Anything going on there that we should be watching? Is there any key differences in the competitive dynamics? And also if 40% of the growth this year was the Target stuff, how does that make you feel about next year's growth opportunities at Hill PHOENIX?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: No. I will try to attempt to answer one question. If you look at the industry data this year, referring to Cases, not Systems but Cases. It would appear that the industry volume is up about 11%. And that a significant piece of that, maybe 40% of that incr
componenttext: No. I will try to attempt to answer one question. If you look at the industry data this year, referring to Cases, not Systems but Cases. It would appear that the industry volume is up about 11%. And that a significant piece of that, maybe 40% of that increase has been as a result of the Target remodel program. Everything we're being told, everything we're hearing is that the Target remodel program will continue into 2011, and it may not be a jump over 2010, but will continue. But at the same time, we also believe there's going to be some rising volume requirements from the other players in the industry in 2011. I don't have an industry forecast for 2011.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: One last question for you, Fluid Management margins, just continue to move higher with a little bit of help from volume, but mid-20s number is phenomenal. What's normalized here at Fluid Management or is this just volume dependent?
componenttext: One last question for you, Fluid Management margins, just continue to move higher with a little bit of help from volume, but mid-20s number is phenomenal. What's normalized here at Fluid Management or is this just volume dependent?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, yes. They have done an outstanding job last year and this year around margin management and volume leverage. It's really difficult to sit here and look at a path to see a 200 basis point improvement in margins over the next couple of years. We're op
componenttext: Well, yes. They have done an outstanding job last year and this year around margin management and volume leverage. It's really difficult to sit here and look at a path to see a 200 basis point improvement in margins over the next couple of years. We're operating at a pretty high level here, Steve.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010

componenttext: You're pretty close to a normalized today.

componenttext: I think the gains that we would have, if you look forward, it's going to be around volume.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from the line of Terry Darling of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from the line of Terry Darling of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Bob, I wonder if we could come back to your comments about optimism around acquisitions. You have had a fair bit of accretion this year from '09 acquisitions. And I'm wondering if you could speak to the profile of sort of the duration of payback, if you w
componenttext: Bob, I wonder if we could come back to your comments about optimism around acquisitions. You have had a fair bit of accretion this year from '09 acquisitions. And I'm wondering if you could speak to the profile of sort of the duration of payback, if you will, on what's in the pipeline and what you're optimistic about? As things move along here, are you seeing deals a little longer dated payback? Or would you also expect to see some accretion in 2010 from acquisitions?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: You mean 2011?
componenttext: You mean 2011?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry, in 2011, yes.
componenttext: I'm sorry, in 2011, yes.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you. We did a good job this year with accretion on the deals that we closed on last year, we're very pleased with that. Gosh, every deal is unique, Terry. I'm trying to sort of do a quick roll down in my mind here of the opportunities we have
componenttext: Well, thank you. We did a good job this year with accretion on the deals that we closed on last year, we're very pleased with that. Gosh, every deal is unique, Terry. I'm trying to sort of do a quick roll down in my mind here of the opportunities we have in our pipeline. And I know Brad's going to correct me here, if I give you a wrong answer. But let me put it this way, if we took every opportunity in our pipeline and closed on those deals January 1, I believe that our acquisition transactions, all closing on January 1, would be accretive in 2011. You're going to get some different characteristics on each deal, but I believe in total that they would be accretive toward 2011 if we were to close on January 1. Beyond that, I'm not sure how to answer your question.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think what you're saying is essentially the payback duration is pretty similar. You do have a fair bit of year one accretive deals in the pipeline, question is actually execution, we all appreciate that.
componenttext: I think what you're saying is essentially the payback duration is pretty similar. You do have a fair bit of year one accretive deals in the pipeline, question is actually execution, we all appreciate that.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's going to be the execution on individual deals. It's also going to be the closing date. We've got a few deals that if we weren't able to close on them until mid-year, because of the deal cost and some upfront purchase accounting costs, you just lose t
componenttext: It's going to be the execution on individual deals. It's also going to be the closing date. We've got a few deals that if we weren't able to close on them until mid-year, because of the deal cost and some upfront purchase accounting costs, you just lose time to cover.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then wondering how you're thinking about incremental margins, and maybe we get Brad involved on this into 2011 and the volume leverage in the business typically around 30% or so, I think you're pretty much there if you pull out that debt extinguishmen
componenttext: And then wondering how you're thinking about incremental margins, and maybe we get Brad involved on this into 2011 and the volume leverage in the business typically around 30% or so, I think you're pretty much there if you pull out that debt extinguishment item in this quarter. You've got the centralization, cost savings, potentially on top of that and the other side as you pointed out in your opening comments, you've moved R&D up a little bit, you've moved emerging markets investments up a little bit as well. But as we go into 2011, should we think about incrementals in that normal 30% range because the incremental savings are going to be offset with incremental investment? Or do you see a little bit more drop through next year as the savings start to move ahead of the incremental investments?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess, Terry, what I would say is third quarter is more like we'd expect going forward. So earlier in the year, first half of the year, let's say, we were converting volume at a higher lever drop through. And the third quarter, you're right, it's about
componenttext: I guess, Terry, what I would say is third quarter is more like we'd expect going forward. So earlier in the year, first half of the year, let's say, we were converting volume at a higher lever drop through. And the third quarter, you're right, it's about at that 30%, a little over 30% range. And as I think about going into next year, given the investments we're making. Dave's talked about investments in our Solar business. We continue to invest in Knowles, a lot of different investments in our energy space, I would see that we'll continue to do that for growth, and therefore, the incremental drop through should be more in that low 30% range. That's where I see it.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: And maybe just to clarify, the impact on growth I think once generally multi-industry companies get through the turn in the cycle, you see organic moderate back to the mid-singles. Does your growth investments and you talked about Knowles as one example o
componenttext: And maybe just to clarify, the impact on growth I think once generally multi-industry companies get through the turn in the cycle, you see organic moderate back to the mid-singles. Does your growth investments and you talked about Knowles as one example of that, next year with the Apple opportunity and maybe more closer to that 20% range. Do you move the overall organic for the company into the upper singles as you get into that kind of normalized environment? Or are you offsetting some pressures on the maturing parts of the portfolio just to stay in that mid-single range?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think you have to recognize that going into 2011, at least from our perspective, we see ourselves beyond the recession and beyond the balance. If you want to look at the first half of '10 incorporating some type of balance from the downturn. And now we'
componenttext: I think you have to recognize that going into 2011, at least from our perspective, we see ourselves beyond the recession and beyond the balance. If you want to look at the first half of '10 incorporating some type of balance from the downturn. And now we're in the early years of whatever that up cycle is going to look like. We've given long-range guidance. We did this a year ago at Dover Day of 4% to 5% organic growth longer-term through the cycle. I would expect -- I think we all expect that in the early years of the cycle that the growth rate could be a little bit better than the 4% or 5%. Anything beyond that, I'm going to defer to some commentary around Dover Day. And we are going to provide a framework, not only for next year, but how we're looking at the next two to three years as part of our dialogue at Dover Day.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your final question comes from the line of Shannon O'Callaghan with Nomura.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your final question comes from the line of Shannon O'Callaghan with Nomura.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, don't look at the rate of improvement in margins at Electronic Technologies 2010 versus 2009 as something that we can repeat again next year. But if you look at the range, it has a lot to do with product mix. It has a lot to do with customer mix and
componenttext: Well, don't look at the rate of improvement in margins at Electronic Technologies 2010 versus 2009 as something that we can repeat again next year. But if you look at the range, it has a lot to do with product mix. It has a lot to do with customer mix and it has a lot to do with where you are in the cycle. Absent a very strong downturn, we believe that structurally, we've got the portfolio and the market balance. Market balance is important here to see the operating margins at DEP being 14% to 18% maybe, Dave, in a really strong period they may nudge a bit higher. But do not sit here and anticipate another 300 or 400 basis point improvement in margins.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010

componenttext: No, I said absent a very strong [indiscernible] (1:00:33). If you look at the downturn that we encountered last year, and gosh, I don't care what your product mix or customer mix looks like, when the customers actually stop ordering, it's hard to maintain margins.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think the only one I'm going to respond to is the end market outlook. You're right, we have continued to see increased North America rig count deployment throughout the year. We even continue to see a very modest increase in the third quarter. We think
componenttext: I think the only one I'm going to respond to is the end market outlook. You're right, we have continued to see increased North America rig count deployment throughout the year. We even continue to see a very modest increase in the third quarter. We think there could be another modest increase in rig count deployment in the fourth quarter. As we look at 2011 and all the data and the forecast from the experts that we're seeing and reading, best case, further modest increase in rig count deployment in 2011. It is not going to be as anywhere near the increase in 2011 like we have seen in 2010 with year-over-year comps.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Third Quarter 2010 Dover Corporation Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to Mr. Paul Goldberg, Treasurer and Director of Investor Relations of Dover Corporation. Mr. Gol
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to the Third Quarter 2010 Dover Corporation Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to Mr. Paul Goldberg, Treasurer and Director of Investor Relations of Dover Corporation. Mr. Goldberg, please go ahead, sir.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jackie. Good morning, and welcome to Dover's Third Quarter Earnings Call. With me today are Bob Livingston, Dover's President and Chief Executive Officer; Brad Cerepak, our CFO; and Dave Van Loan. Dave is President of our Electronic Technologie
componenttext:
Thank you, Jackie. Good morning, and welcome to Dover's Third Quarter Earnings Call. With me today are Bob Livingston, Dover's President and Chief Executive Officer; Brad Cerepak, our CFO; and Dave Van Loan. Dave is President of our Electronic Technologies segment. 
Today's call will begin with comments from Bob and Brad on Dover's third quarter operating and financial performance and our updated outlook for the rest of 2010. We will then open the call up to questions. [Operator Instructions] Please note that our current earnings release, investor supplement and associated presentation can be found on our website, www.dovercorporation.com. This call will be available for playback through November 5, and the audio portion of this call will be archived on our website for three months. The replay telephone number is 1 (800) 642-1687. When accessing the playback, you'll need to supply the following reservation code, 14334215.
Before we get started, I'd like to remind everyone that our comments today, which are intended to supplement your understanding of Dover, may contain certain forward-looking statements that are inherently subject to uncertainties. We caution everyone to be guided in their analysis of Dover Corporation by referring to our Form 10-K for a list of factors that could cause our results to differ from those anticipated in any such forward-looking statement. Also we undertake no obligation to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statements except as required by law. We would also direct your attention to our website where considerably more information can be found.
And with that, I'd like to turn this call over to Bob.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Paul. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us for this morning's conference call. I'm happy to have Dave Van Loan join us today to participate in the Q&A portion of this call. And all for his keen insight on one of our many success storie
componenttext:
Thanks, Paul. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us for this morning's conference call. I'm happy to have Dave Van Loan join us today to participate in the Q&A portion of this call. And all for his keen insight on one of our many success stories this year, the growth in Electronic Technologies.
I am pleased to report Dover saw a strong third quarter gains in revenue, bookings, earnings and margin, reflecting very solid performance across the majority of our companies and the continuing benefits of our productivity initiatives. Orders were up 27% and revenue increased 26%, reflecting the steady improvement in the majority of our end markets. Organic revenue growth was 25%, acquisitions contributed 3%, FX had a negative impact of 2%.
In the third quarter, we saw a continuation of several positive trends that had been prevalent throughout the year. Knowles continued to benefit from the growing handset market, especially the growth in smartphones. DEK is enjoying a strong recovery in the electronic assembly market and increasing demand for their product innovations and solar equipment. U.S. Synthetic has shown tremendous growth driven by the strong rebound in North America rig count, increases in horizontal drilling and share gains. Our Palm Solutions group has seen a steady increase in their business, notably in Asia. This growth in Asia is also evident in our Vehicle Service group, which has seen a nice jump in their activity connected to the China auto market. Lastly, the seasonal ramp up at Hill PHOENIX was even stronger than expected at the beginning of the quarter, largely driven by remodel activity and taking advantage of the recent capacity expansion in our Richmond facility.
Now let's move to our third quarter results and Brad will discuss our guidance later in the call. Today, we reported third quarter revenue of $1.9 billion, an increase of 26% over last year. Earnings per share from continuing operations increased to 103% to $1.18, including tax benefits of $0.20. Adjusted EPS was $0.98, a 69% improvement over last year. On a sequential basis, revenue and adjusted EPS increased 6% and 8%, respectively. Bookings increased 27% over last year to $1.8 billion. Book-to-bill finished at 0.96. 
Segment operating margin for the quarter was 17.1%, up 280 basis points. Year-over-year margins increased significantly at Fluid Management, Electronic Technologies and Industrial Products, while Engineered Systems margin remained strong. This quarterly segment margin result is the highest in recent memory.
In the third quarter, we generated free cash flow of $157 million, 8% of revenue, reflecting an increase in working capital to support our expanding businesses and continued CapEx investments to support our future growth expectations. We are still targeting full year free cash flow to be around 10% of revenue.
Our acquisition pipeline continues to be full and has matured nicely. We closed on three small deals totaling $35 million during the quarter. We have several targets in our five growth spaces and fully expect to close some transactions in the next few months.
I'm quite pleased with our strong performance in the third quarter, especially with regard to revenue growth and operating margin. Our results reflect our company's continued focus on their customers, our cost base and productivity. Our third quarter order rates and backlogs have us well-positioned as we start the fourth quarter. 
With that, let me turn it over to Brad, for comments on our segment performance.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bob. Good morning, everyone. Let's start by turning to Slide 5. As Bob mentioned, sequential revenue increased 6%, reflecting growth across all our segments and platforms. Sequential revenue growth was 10% in Electronic Technologies; 7%, Engineere
componenttext:
Thanks, Bob. Good morning, everyone. Let's start by turning to Slide 5. As Bob mentioned, sequential revenue increased 6%, reflecting growth across all our segments and platforms. Sequential revenue growth was 10% in Electronic Technologies; 7%, Engineered Systems, and we saw more modest growth in Fluid Management and Industrial Products. 
On a sequential basis, bookings declined 6% in the quarter, principally reflecting normal seasonality. The sequential decline in engineered products, consistent with last year's experience, was largely attributable to Hill PHOENIX. 
In addition, mobile equipment was impacted by military order booked in the second quarter, which amplified the modest seasonality normally seen in this platform. 
With respect to geographic growth, Latin America was our fastest growing region in the third quarter with a growth rate of 48%, Asia grew 41%, North America grew at 26%, while Europe was up 19%. Our companies remain focused on growing their businesses in the Asian and Latin American markets. Also of note, the third quarter marks the first time our Asian revenue exceeded Europe's revenue in absolute dollar terms.
Turning to Slide 6. Industrial products posted revenue of $471 million and $59 million of earnings, an increase of 19% and 56%, respectively. This strong earnings performance was a result of increased volume across Material Handling, productivity and leverage on a lower cost base. 
Bookings were $456 million, an increase of 29%, reflecting broad-based year-over-year improvement. Sequentially, bookings were down 11%, resulting in a book-to-bill of 0.97. 
Industrial Products quarterly operating margin was 12.6%, up 300 basis points from last year and 20 basis points sequentially, adjusting for a one-time gain in the second quarter. Again, our earlier rightsizing actions continue to put this segment in a strong position to leverage any further increases in demand. 
With respect to our Material Handling platform, sales increased 43% to $221 million. Earnings nearly tripled, driven by increased activity across most end markets, and each operating company delivered double-digit revenue growth. In total, Material Handling margins were up 760 basis points, reflecting strong conversion on volume.
For the quarter, bookings were $223 million, an increase of 37% over last year and flat sequentially, yielding a book-to-bill of 1.01. North American residential construction trends continue to show modest improvement.
With respect to our Mobile Equipment platform, sales were $251 million, up 4% from last year, and earnings were essentially flat. Margins decreased 50 basis points, primarily reflecting product mix. Those sequential bookings declined 6% after adjusting for a large Q2 military order that increased 22% year-over-year to $234 million. This improvement was driven by international growth at Vehicle Services Group and the beginnings of a recovery in selected trailer markets. Book-to-bill finished at 0.93.
Turning to Slide 7. At Engineered Systems, we posted record quarterly revenue and earnings. Sales were $620 million, an increase of 19%, and segment earnings increased 17% to $91 million. The year-over-year growth in revenue is largely attributable to strong performances at Hill PHOENIX in Bellevue. For the quarter, operating margin was 14.7%, a 30 basis point decline from last year and flat, sequentially. Bookings were $547 million, an increase of 16% over the prior year.
On a sequential basis, bookings reflected the normal seasonal patterns and were down 9% resulting in a book-to-bill of 0.88.
Our Product Identification platform continue to benefit from strong demand in developing economies. Third quarter sales were $222 million, an increase of 5%, which included a negative FX impact of 2%. Year-over-year earnings were flat, and margins decreased 90 basis points. Margin performance was impacted by increased investment in R&D and business development activities in emerging markets and revenue mix. Book-to-bill was 0.98.
Moving to Engineered Products. Third quarter sales were $399 million, an increase in revenue of 29% with acquisitions accounting for 8% of the growth. Earnings increased 33%, resulting in margin expansion of 40 basis points over last year and 10 basis points, sequentially. Favorable margin performance was largely driven by volume improvements, which were partially offset by product and customer mix and continued price material cost spread at SWEP. Engineered products bookings were $329 million, an increase of 27% over the prior year, primarily driven by Hill PHOENIX and aided by the Barker acquisition of last year. Sequential bookings declined 13% in the third quarter, resulting in a book-to-bill of 0.83. This result reflects normal seasonal order patterns at Hill PHOENIX.
Now moving to Slide 8. At Fluid Management, revenue increased 35% to $416 million, while earnings increased 68% to $102 million. Third quarter operating margin was 24.5%, a 490 basis point expansion over last year and an increase of 70 basis points, sequentially. Bookings were $409 million, an increase of 26% over the prior year, resulting in a book-to-bill of 0.98. 
With respect to our Energy platform, revenue increased 52% to $220 million while earnings increased 80%. Margin improved 480 basis points on significantly higher volume, driven by an expanding North American rig count, including an increase in horizontal drilling and productivity gains.  Quarterly bookings increased 35% to $213 million, but declined 6% sequentially off an extremely strong second quarter. Book-to-bill was 0.97. The end markets in this platform remain healthy and our businesses are well-positioned. Looking forward in Q4, we anticipate North American rig count to be modestly positive.
Moving to Fluid Solutions. This platform generated revenue of $197 million, an increase of 19%. Earnings increased 45%, resulting in 390 basis point margin improvement, a tremendous performance. Bookings increased 18% year-over-year to $196 million, and book-to-bill remained steady at one. We are seeing a continuation of modest improvement in most of these platform-served markets and our Pump group continues to make great inroads in developing regions especially Asia.
Turning to Slide 9. Electronic Technologies revenue was $381 million, an increase of 39%. The majority of end markets in this segment were up significantly year-over-year with continuing strong demand for electronic assembly equipments, MEMS microphones, Passive Components and our emerging solar products. Earnings were $70 million, an 82% improvement over last year. Operating margin was 18.3%, driven by significantly higher volume and strong conversion on an improved cost base. Bookings were $402 million, up 42% over last year. Book-to-bill continues to be solid at 1.05.
Our electronic assembly equipment companies posted a 65% jump in revenue year-over-year, and continue to see improving order book for the sixth consecutive quarter. Book-to-bill was 1.14. Although we anticipate some normal seasonal softness in fourth quarter, we expect the climate in the electronic assembly markets to remain positive.
Lastly, our communication components companies posted another solid quarter, reflecting continued strength in Knowles, CMP and Vectron. We ended the quarter with a book-to-bill of one, although we did see some moderation in the telecom infrastructure market as we enter the fourth quarter.
Having reviewed the segments, I'd now would like to briefly provide some additional financial data. 
Moving to Slide 10. Second quarter net interest expense was $26 million, flat with last year and in line with our full year guidance. Our net debt to total capitalization was 14.8%, down 360 basis points from year end, largely reflecting higher cash balances and lower debt. 
With respect to taxes, our third quarter tax rate was largely impacted by U.S. tax settlements and a resolution of a foreign tax position, resulting in a benefit of $0.20 EPS in the quarter. This is comprised of two elements: $0.15 EPS related to a discrete tax settlement in the quarter; and $0.05 EPS related to the reduction of the annual effective tax rate. We now expect the annual full year tax rate, inclusive of the previously mentioned $0.20 of tax benefits to be about 25.5%. Corporate expenses were up slightly from last year and were impacted by a one-time $4.3 million charge associated with the early extinguishment of debt.
Turning to Slide 11. As discussed, third quarter revenue and bookings were strong for us across Dover. We now expect full year revenue growth, including acquisitions, to be in the range of 20% to 21%. Here's the breakdown by segment of our revenue growth: we expect that Industrial Products revenue should grow 11% to 12%; Engineered Systems revenue should increase 17% to 18%, including acquisition growth of 9%; Fluid Management revenue growth should be in the range of 25% to 26%, including 3% from acquisitions; lastly, Electronic Technologies should sharply grow revenue at the mid-30% level, with no material impact from acquisitions.
Now let's go to the full year earnings bridge on Slide 12. Volume remains the biggest driver of the increase in earnings. Volume, product mix and pricing should improve earnings $1.11 to $1.20 while restructuring and productivity will have a continuing impact as well. Our acquisitions continue to perform at a high level and will now deliver $0.13 for the year. Corporate expense is roughly in line with previous estimates. Compensation expense is a function of our improved revenue and earnings forecast. 
Lastly, tax significantly increases our revised forecast. We add $0.20 to our forecast to reflect discrete tax benefits in the quarter. And the impact of the reduction of the annual effective rate. As a result, we are now increasing our full year EPS guidance and expect to be in the range of $3.50 to $3.55. 
Now I'd like to turn the call back over to Bob.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Brad. We've had three great quarters and fully expect to finish the year in good form. In addition, we've made great progress in further establishing a foundation for growth. Throughout the year, we've made investments in product innovation, capac
componenttext:
Thanks, Brad. We've had three great quarters and fully expect to finish the year in good form. In addition, we've made great progress in further establishing a foundation for growth. Throughout the year, we've made investments in product innovation, capacity, supply chains, people and geographic expansion. We focused on our five growth spaces: Refrigeration and Food Equipment, Fluid Solutions, Energy, Product ID and Communication Components. We believe these spaces offer us the greatest opportunity to grow, both organically and through acquisitions. 
Lastly, the opportunities for growth in developing economies are significant for Dover. As Brett mentioned earlier, third quarter revenue in Asia was larger than in Europe. I would expect this trend to continue. I am excited with our growth's prospects, and look forward to sharing our outlook with you at our Investor Day in New York on November 15. And in closing, I'd like to personally thank everyone at Dover for all their efforts and contributions to a very positive third quarter. 
With that, back to Paul.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bob. At this point, I just like to remind everybody again, if you can limit yourself to one question with a follow-up, we'll be better positioned to answer everybody's questions. And with that, I'd like to turn it over to Jackie.
componenttext:
Thanks, Bob. At this point, I just like to remind everybody again, if you can limit yourself to one question with a follow-up, we'll be better positioned to answer everybody's questions. 
And with that, I'd like to turn it over to Jackie.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from John Inch of Bank of America.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from John Inch of Bank of America.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: If I go to the annual core revenue guide, call it 17% at the midpoint, and you add up the first three quarters and you look traditionally at the fourth quarter, and I know you've got about, I believe, five points of tougher sequential comp. Forgetting abo
componenttext: If I go to the annual core revenue guide, call it 17% at the midpoint, and you add up the first three quarters and you look traditionally at the fourth quarter, and I know you've got about, I believe, five points of tougher sequential comp. Forgetting about the seasonal impact, because this would be captured in the year-over-year, it does look like you're suggesting fourth quarter kind of around 12% organic growth, a down from 25% with maybe five points of tougher comp. Is there something else in the mix? I'm not talking about just the seasonality, but maybe pull forward, say, from fourth quarter to third quarter? Or are you just trying to set the bar low for some reason that perhaps we're not seeing? Just any color would be helpful?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Brad may correct me here, but I think at the midpoint of our fourth quarter outlook here, I think the organic growth rate year-over-year was probably going to be around 13%, I think I heard you said 12%.
componenttext: Brad may correct me here, but I think at the midpoint of our fourth quarter outlook here, I think the organic growth rate year-over-year was probably going to be around 13%, I think I heard you said 12%.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes 12%, 13%. Sure, yes.
componenttext: Yes 12%, 13%. Sure, yes.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's about right, John. And yes, we do have a tougher comp. But beyond that, it is seasonality. If you look at the midpoint of our revenue range, we're expecting fourth quarter revenue of about $1.7 billion, $1.10 billion. That's about $175 million drop
componenttext: That's about right, John. And yes, we do have a tougher comp. But beyond that, it is seasonality. If you look at the midpoint of our revenue range, we're expecting fourth quarter revenue of about $1.7 billion, $1.10 billion. That's about $175 million drop, sequentially. John, $110 million, $115 million of that drop is at Hill PHOENIX. And it is the seasonal pattern we're dealing with at Hill PHOENIX.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I know Hill PHOENIX was a little lumpy sometimes, did it have an unusually good quarter this quarter? Or there's nothing about anything else with the moving parts of it?
componenttext: I know Hill PHOENIX was a little lumpy sometimes, did it have an unusually good quarter this quarter? Or there's nothing about anything else with the moving parts of it?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: They had a superb third quarter. I think probably the only characteristic for their third quarter that was perhaps different than what they typically see is that as we enter each month, as we enter each quarter, and look at our backlog and our factory loa
componenttext: They had a superb third quarter. I think probably the only characteristic for their third quarter that was perhaps different than what they typically see is that as we enter each month, as we enter each quarter, and look at our backlog and our factory loading, we know that as we enter the month and enter the quarter, there's always the possibility of shipment deferrals by customers as we close the month or close the quarter. I would say the difference in the third quarter, we had very, very few customer deferrals in the third quarter. In fact, there may have been a few million dollars or even fourth quarter pull-ins into the third quarter.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well that makes sense, because I think some of your big customers have later fiscal years, if I'm not mistaken.
componenttext: Well that makes sense, because I think some of your big customers have later fiscal years, if I'm not mistaken.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me give you another data point.
componenttext: Let me give you another data point.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure.
componenttext: Sure.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: This $110 million, $115 million decline at Hill PHOENIX for the fourth quarter, John, it's a big number. It's a 43% decline from the third quarter. And I will admit, we've never seen, we have never seen that level of decline at Hill PHOENIX from third qua
componenttext: This $110 million, $115 million decline at Hill PHOENIX for the fourth quarter, John, it's a big number. It's a 43% decline from the third quarter. And I will admit, we've never seen, we have never seen that level of decline at Hill PHOENIX from third quarter to fourth quarter. Even last year, when we were expecting this significant decline, that decline last year was 32%, 34%. And I think the characteristic that is changing here, not just with Hill PHOENIX but in the industry, we've shared these data points with you before that if you go back four or five years, about 40% of our business was remodeled. That percentage has been increasing. Last year, our remodel activity was about 60% of our volume. Third quarter, it was a 75% of our business. Fourth quarter, I would expect that percentage to hold true for the fourth quarter as well. We get into the remodel activity into the fourth quarter. We're not going to ship much product to customers between the 1st of November and the end of December. They just do not want to disrupt the customer flow in the store.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's interesting. So on a year-over-year basis, what you're suggesting is the remodel impact is actually beginning to shift or mix shift Hill PHOENIX's third quarter to become even more stronger over time most likely?
componenttext: That's interesting. So on a year-over-year basis, what you're suggesting is the remodel impact is actually beginning to shift or mix shift Hill PHOENIX's third quarter to become even more stronger over time most likely?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. And you look at the share of our remodel business, there's a share of our total. This number that we hit in the third quarter is 75%. We're plowing new ground. We've never had that level of remodel business for Hill PHOENIX.
componenttext: Yes. And you look at the share of our remodel business, there's a share of our total. This number that we hit in the third quarter is 75%. We're plowing new ground. We've never had that level of remodel business for Hill PHOENIX.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Bob, I know you're going to talk about supply chain at Dover Days, so I won't go there, but you do have $1.5 billion of overhead or SG&A costs on the books in '09. What are your thoughts toward at some point, perhaps looking to maybe apply some of the cen
componenttext: Bob, I know you're going to talk about supply chain at Dover Days, so I won't go there, but you do have $1.5 billion of overhead or SG&A costs on the books in '09. What are your thoughts toward at some point, perhaps looking to maybe apply some of the centralization activities that you've been applying toward supply chain and some other areas of Dover to overhead and I don't even know if preliminarily, you might have a view that, is there an opportunity or is there not? And again, not expecting you to do this right away, but I'm just sort of thinking over time, how you're thinking about that opportunity?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: We would think about that over time, John. And that's probably the only response I'm going to give you on today's call. I think we may chat a little bit more about that on Dover Day.
componenttext: We would think about that over time, John. And that's probably the only response I'm going to give you on today's call. I think we may chat a little bit more about that on Dover Day.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Jeff Sprague with Vertical Research Partners.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Jeff Sprague with Vertical Research Partners.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Bob, first, if you could provide a little more color on the M&A front and certainly the data point about Asia surpassing Europe is very interesting. Is the M&A biased towards any particular geography at this point? Usually, it's hard to find things to do
componenttext: Bob, first, if you could provide a little more color on the M&A front and certainly the data point about Asia surpassing Europe is very interesting. Is the M&A biased towards any particular geography at this point? Usually, it's hard to find things to do in Asia, but any color there would be helpful.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't change your comment about Asia. It is hard to find things in Asia, Jeff. The comment around Asia being larger than Europe, this was the first time we've ever achieved that. And it was slight, but I want to take credit for it. And I think it ref
componenttext: I wouldn't change your comment about Asia. It is hard to find things in Asia, Jeff. The comment around Asia being larger than Europe, this was the first time we've ever achieved that. And it was slight, but I want to take credit for it. And I think it reflects a lot of people investment, a lot of capital investment that we've made around the Dover businesses over the last 12 months. Comments on the M&A pipeline, our activity, our closure transactions in the third quarter, I'd use the phrase, rather modest. We do have a rather full pipeline. I'm actually very enthused and excited with the opportunities in our pipeline. I wouldn't -- I don't think there's a preponderance of focus either in U.S. or outside of the U.S. I think almost all of the opportunities in our pipeline are in our five targeted spaces. And as I said in my prepared comments, I think we're going to make some acquisitions and close some acquisitions here in the next few months.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Asia is obviously the nexus of a lot of the electronic activity. Just wondering if you'd just respond a little bit and then you have your colleague there. I'm just -- the tone of business looking into next year, there seems to be a lot of anxiety about ma
componenttext: Asia is obviously the nexus of a lot of the electronic activity. Just wondering if you'd just respond a little bit and then you have your colleague there. I'm just -- the tone of business looking into next year, there seems to be a lot of anxiety about maybe text slowing down, book-to-bill looking a little softer, where is the consumer? Just in terms of what you can see in terms of what your customers have planned into next year, you're coming off a tough comp. How do we think about the growth next year?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jeff, this is Dave. We're were talking a lot about next year about Dover Day, but I can share with you some of the industry data we have out there right now. Both Semi and VLSI have recently reduced their equipment projections for next year. Semi is looki
componenttext: Jeff, this is Dave. We're were talking a lot about next year about Dover Day, but I can share with you some of the industry data we have out there right now. Both Semi and VLSI have recently reduced their equipment projections for next year. Semi is looking at equipment going flat. VLSI is only expecting about 2% equipment growth. If they're right and there's certainly no guarantee of that, our business will clearly be impacted also. But right now, our customer's fabs are absolutely running flat out. And I could also share with you another subject where I'll talk about more at Dover Day. But our program for expanding the core of our businesses in the Tech business, this initiative we talked about before, this is where we're taking our existing technology and adapting it for adjacent markets. We feel this has put us in a position for our business to continue to grow. Solar, our solar program that we've mentioned earlier, is a great example of that. In 2008, our Solar business was effectively zero. In 2009, that business jumped to about 1% of DET's shipments, which is really not bad for new product introduction. In 2010, solar revenues we expect them to at least triple, and I would add that these are very nice margins in this business at the same time. So we'll talk more about expanding the core, which is frankly our initiative to address kind of the lumpiness in the volatility in the Tech business.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: And also, Jeff, I would just point out that this Semi and electronic assembly is increasingly a smaller part of the overall Dover Electronic segment.
componenttext: And also, Jeff, I would just point out that this Semi and electronic assembly is increasingly a smaller part of the overall Dover Electronic segment.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Chris Weltzer of Robert W. Baird & Co.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Chris Weltzer of Robert W. Baird & Co.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Wondering if you could talk a little bit about, I mean, you've got the highest cash balance, at least that I can find now that you've ever heard had in Dover's history. I know there is, the acquisition pipeline's full and opportunities are always out ther
componenttext: Wondering if you could talk a little bit about, I mean, you've got the highest cash balance, at least that I can find now that you've ever heard had in Dover's history. I know there is, the acquisition pipeline's full and opportunities are always out there. But has there been any discussion about resuming share repurchase activity, especially since rates on new debt if you ended up needing cash for another deal would be relatively low at this point?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, we are not looking at share repurchase activity any time in the next few quarters, and we think we've got enough acquisition opportunities that we're going to smartly deploy that cash.
componenttext: No, we are not looking at share repurchase activity any time in the next few quarters, and we think we've got enough acquisition opportunities that we're going to smartly deploy that cash.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just wondering if you could dig in to the comments that you made about Hill PHOENIX and remodel becoming a bigger piece of that business, do you find that, that's an industry phenomenon? Is that something an area where you're gaining share or attempting t
componenttext: Just wondering if you could dig in to the comments that you made about Hill PHOENIX and remodel becoming a bigger piece of that business, do you find that, that's an industry phenomenon? Is that something an area where you're gaining share or attempting to differentiate yourself from your competitors? Just a little bit of color there'll be helpful.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: You'll have an opportunity to ask a little bit more of a detailed question of Ray Hoglund, who runs the DES segment at Dover Day, but let me try to give you a little bit of color on that right now. This is a little bit of a recall here, but I'm going to s
componenttext: You'll have an opportunity to ask a little bit more of a detailed question of Ray Hoglund, who runs the DES segment at Dover Day, but let me try to give you a little bit of color on that right now. This is a little bit of a recall here, but I'm going to speak to the Case business, not the entire business because we do see some industry data on cases. It's difficult to see the industry data on refrigeration systems. Case business growth in North America, the date we see shows an 11% growth through the third quarter. My guess is, our guess is, that about 40% of that growth this year is actually due to their Target program, the remodel program, the store layout program every month at Target. On the case business, 11% growth in the industry, we think our growth in the Case business year-to-date has been about 23%. Now, that includes a little bit of pop from the acquisition activity of Barker in the fourth quarter. I think everyone in the industry has benefited from the increase in case volume this year. Clearly, in the third quarter, the demand in the industry was strong enough, that I think the suppliers were struggling a little bit with capacity and customer demands.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: So do those numbers -- are you trying to infer that you've won more than your fair share of the Target business? And what are your thoughts on your portion of that business that may happen next year?
componenttext: So do those numbers -- are you trying to infer that you've won more than your fair share of the Target business? And what are your thoughts on your portion of that business that may happen next year?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I'm not going to speak to the Target business. We've been pleased with the participation that we've enjoyed with Target. If you want to comment on share, I keep looking and sharing with the investor community the progress that Hill PHOENIX has made
componenttext: Well, I'm not going to speak to the Target business. We've been pleased with the participation that we've enjoyed with Target. If you want to comment on share, I keep looking and sharing with the investor community the progress that Hill PHOENIX has made over the last several years, not just on a quarterly basis or a half year basis. And over the last six or seven years, we've seen our market share in the Case business grow from the high teens or low 20. We think by the time we close the third quarter, we think our market share year-to-date in the Case business, including the acquisitions we made last year, is about 37%, 38%. I want to add something to both your question and an earlier question, when I talk about this high percentage of our business being remodeled, we expect that to continue. We don't see that changing in the next two to three years.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010

componenttext: The tax other line in the continuing playtime guidance ops bridge, got call it $0.10, $0.14 less of a drag. Is there anything unusual in that number? Is that just other income?

componenttext: You're looking at the earnings bridge? That tax line, there's two tax lines there. One is for the discrete $0.20 that we spoke about, the other line really is just a comparison of tax year-over-year, but nothing unusual in there. But you do recall, we did have a discrete item in last year's second quarter. So that's part of what you see in that second line.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Scott Davis with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: When you look at the just phenomenal growth you've had in Electronic Tech, I mean if that's kind of the question and particularly in MEMS microphones, where are you in relation to kind of capacity? And at what point do you need to add capacity or kind of
componenttext: When you look at the just phenomenal growth you've had in Electronic Tech, I mean if that's kind of the question and particularly in MEMS microphones, where are you in relation to kind of capacity? And at what point do you need to add capacity or kind of how scalable is your production? And the following question to that is really what are your competitors doing? And I know you have very large shares and such, but often times, when you have growth rates like this, you have time to see a more aggressive competitive response. So maybe you could address both of those issues?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Scott, was your question all around MEMS? We understood the first part, the second part of that competitors, you were referring to MEMS?
componenttext: Scott, was your question all around MEMS? We understood the first part, the second part of that competitors, you were referring to MEMS?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, you could broaden it out. I mean I was speaking to -- I mean, thinking in terms of kind of example being MEMS, but you could speak to the whole segment if you'd like.
componenttext: Yes, you could broaden it out. I mean I was speaking to -- I mean, thinking in terms of kind of example being MEMS, but you could speak to the whole segment if you'd like.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'll take it off, Dave's chomping at the major to jump in with a quick response. But if you look at the MEMS business, we've owned Knowles now for five years and a month. I don't think there's been a year since they've been part of Dover that we haven't h
componenttext: I'll take it off, Dave's chomping at the major to jump in with a quick response. But if you look at the MEMS business, we've owned Knowles now for five years and a month. I don't think there's been a year since they've been part of Dover that we haven't had capacity addition projects. We did it in '09 during the downturn. We've got additional capacity adding projects underway for '10 that could come online or they should come online by the end of the first quarter going into the second quarter of next year. And if you look at our long-term planning, we expect additional projects to fund next year. To give you a magnitude, this year, our capacity add projects at Knowles will be about a $20 million investment. We are trying to not only support the growth at Knowles, but trying to stay in front of the growth with enough capacity adds that we don't constrain our delivery or disrupt our customers. With that, Dave can probably add a little bit more color.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Scott, your question about the competition, it might surprise you, when we look at our competition in this business, we're really looking more at our traditional ECM microphone competitors than alternative suppliers in the MEMS microphone business. So the
componenttext: Scott, your question about the competition, it might surprise you, when we look at our competition in this business, we're really looking more at our traditional ECM microphone competitors than alternative suppliers in the MEMS microphone business. So there are a number of cellphones out there today that are still using ECM mics. We look at that as a great opportunity. This is a growth opportunity for us to convert these customers to MEMS technology, which has a tremendous number of advantages in that area. On the competitors in the MEMS side of the business, strangely enough, that's actually, we look at that as a good thing. We don't see anybody with huge capacity or huge wins out there today. But having that second source for our customers actually helps us in our quest to bring more of the ECM customers across as they have a second source.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Am I to assume that the $20 million investment is pretty much all entirely China?
componenttext: Am I to assume that the $20 million investment is pretty much all entirely China?

componenttext: Asia.

componenttext: It's outside of China too?

componenttext: Yes. We've got facilities in Malaysia as well.

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Steve Tusa of JPMorgan.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: You had a pretty dramatic ramp at Knowles this year. What was that business up in the quarter?
componenttext: You had a pretty dramatic ramp at Knowles this year. What was that business up in the quarter?

componenttextpreview: I don't have that data in front of me. Do you want to take a guess at that response? The revenue third quarter increased, maybe a little bit better than 20%.
componenttext: I don't have that data in front of me. Do you want to take a guess at that response? The revenue third quarter increased, maybe a little bit better than 20%.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: So actually less than the segment increase?
componenttext: So actually less than the segment increase?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: For sure. You look at the growth and Dave can give you some color on this, but you look at the growth in not just the third quarter, but the second quarter on the organic growth rates. The comps were extremely favorable for the equipment companies. They'v
componenttext: For sure. You look at the growth and Dave can give you some color on this, but you look at the growth in not just the third quarter, but the second quarter on the organic growth rates. The comps were extremely favorable for the equipment companies. They've not only had a great year this year, but as we all know, they really struggled with the downturn in the first half of '09. Interestingly, Steve, we did not see the decline even though we saw some decline, we did not see the sharpness and decline in our Communication Components business in 2009 like we saw in our equipment businesses.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: So does the Component business was up solidly, but not as much as the segment. And next year, are there any dynamics around timing of platform ramps or anything like that, that would lead to anything but kind of a normal year at those Components businesse
componenttext: So does the Component business was up solidly, but not as much as the segment. And next year, are there any dynamics around timing of platform ramps or anything like that, that would lead to anything but kind of a normal year at those Components businesses, including Knowles?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the Knowles business, Steve, is we're looking at the opportunity for one of our major customers, who've recently announced the partnering with a release for Verizon. This is obviously Apple, and we see this as a real opportunity for our business to
componenttext: Well, the Knowles business, Steve, is we're looking at the opportunity for one of our major customers, who've recently announced the partnering with a release for Verizon. This is obviously Apple, and we see this as a real opportunity for our business to take off in that area. When we look at some of these high-end cellphones or high-end smartphones, it's not just a matter of a single microphone anymore. We actually have applications today where we've got two mics in place for active noise cancellation and the third mic is used for voice activation on the phone. So these are very dramatic markets. The share back-and-forth between our various customers is a very positive opportunity for us, and the multiple mic phenomena just continues to gain traction.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: So does that business actually accelerate next year from a revenue growth perspective?
componenttext: So does that business actually accelerate next year from a revenue growth perspective?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll see.
componenttext: We'll see.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: We certainly are very, very optimistic about that market in that space.
componenttext: We certainly are very, very optimistic about that market in that space.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: And just to be clear, you guys are seeing no weakness in the Equipment side of things? Any push outs or anything like that on the equipment side?
componenttext: And just to be clear, you guys are seeing no weakness in the Equipment side of things? Any push outs or anything like that on the equipment side?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: We've seen no push outs at all. We have a very solid backlog for the fourth quarter, and we expect to finish the good performance we've had this year. We expect that to continue and to finish on in very good form.
componenttext: We've seen no push outs at all. We have a very solid backlog for the fourth quarter, and we expect to finish the good performance we've had this year. We expect that to continue and to finish on in very good form.

componenttext: One of your competitors in display cases, I'm not sure, if you've already gone through this and just tell me and I'll just read the transcript. You guys are talking about kind of normal seasonality, Hill PHOENIX, maybe not just timing of orders or something. And Anything going on there that we should be watching? Is there any key differences in the competitive dynamics? And also if 40% of the growth this year was the Target stuff, how does that make you feel about next year's growth opportunities at Hill PHOENIX?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we've answered a lot of this in previous questions, Steve, so I am going to ask you to go back and read the transcript.
componenttext: Well, we've answered a lot of this in previous questions, Steve, so I am going to ask you to go back and read the transcript.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
