componenttext: OK that's fine, but then next year? Did you talk about next year's dynamics?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: No. I will try to attempt to answer one question. If you look at the industry data this year, referring to Cases, not Systems but Cases. It would appear that the industry volume is up about 11%. And that a significant piece of that, maybe 40% of that incr
componenttext: No. I will try to attempt to answer one question. If you look at the industry data this year, referring to Cases, not Systems but Cases. It would appear that the industry volume is up about 11%. And that a significant piece of that, maybe 40% of that increase has been as a result of the Target remodel program. Everything we're being told, everything we're hearing is that the Target remodel program will continue into 2011, and it may not be a jump over 2010, but will continue. But at the same time, we also believe there's going to be some rising volume requirements from the other players in the industry in 2011. I don't have an industry forecast for 2011.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: One last question for you, Fluid Management margins, just continue to move higher with a little bit of help from volume, but mid-20s number is phenomenal. What's normalized here at Fluid Management or is this just volume dependent?
componenttext: One last question for you, Fluid Management margins, just continue to move higher with a little bit of help from volume, but mid-20s number is phenomenal. What's normalized here at Fluid Management or is this just volume dependent?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, yes. They have done an outstanding job last year and this year around margin management and volume leverage. It's really difficult to sit here and look at a path to see a 200 basis point improvement in margins over the next couple of years. We're op
componenttext: Well, yes. They have done an outstanding job last year and this year around margin management and volume leverage. It's really difficult to sit here and look at a path to see a 200 basis point improvement in margins over the next couple of years. We're operating at a pretty high level here, Steve.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: You're pretty close to a normalized today.
componenttext: You're pretty close to a normalized today.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think the gains that we would have, if you look forward, it's going to be around volume.
componenttext: I think the gains that we would have, if you look forward, it's going to be around volume.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from the line of Terry Darling of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from the line of Terry Darling of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Bob, I wonder if we could come back to your comments about optimism around acquisitions. You have had a fair bit of accretion this year from '09 acquisitions. And I'm wondering if you could speak to the profile of sort of the duration of payback, if you w
componenttext: Bob, I wonder if we could come back to your comments about optimism around acquisitions. You have had a fair bit of accretion this year from '09 acquisitions. And I'm wondering if you could speak to the profile of sort of the duration of payback, if you will, and what's in the pipeline and what you're optimistic about? But as things move along here, are you seeing deals a little longer dated payback? Or would you also expect to see some accretion in 2010 from acquisitions?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: You mean 2011?
componenttext: You mean 2011?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry, in 2011, yes.
componenttext: I'm sorry, in 2011, yes.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you. We did a good job this year with accretion on the deals that we closed on last year, we're very pleased with that. Gosh, every deal is unique, Terry. I'm trying to sort of do a quick roll down in my mind here of the opportunities we have
componenttext: Well, thank you. We did a good job this year with accretion on the deals that we closed on last year, we're very pleased with that. Gosh, every deal is unique, Terry. I'm trying to sort of do a quick roll down in my mind here of the opportunities we have in our pipeline. And I know Brad's going to correct me here, if I give you a wrong answer. But let me put it this way, if we took every opportunity on our pipeline and closed on those deals January 1, I believe that our acquisition transactions, all closing on January 1, would be accretive in 2011. You're going to get some different characteristics on each deal, but I believe in total that they would be accretive toward 2011 if we were to close on January 1. Beyond that, I'm not sure how to answer your question.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think what you're saying is essentially the payback duration is pretty similar. You do have a fair bit of your one accretive deals in the pipeline, question is actually execution, we all appreciate that.
componenttext: I think what you're saying is essentially the payback duration is pretty similar. You do have a fair bit of your one accretive deals in the pipeline, question is actually execution, we all appreciate that.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's going to be the execution on individual deals. It's also going to be the closing thing. We've got a few deals that if we weren't able to close on them until mid-year, because of the deal cost and some upfront purchase accounting costs, you just lose
componenttext: It's going to be the execution on individual deals. It's also going to be the closing thing. We've got a few deals that if we weren't able to close on them until mid-year, because of the deal cost and some upfront purchase accounting costs, you just lose time to cover.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then wondering how you're thinking about incremental margins, and maybe we get Brad involved in this into 2011 and the volume leverage in the business typically around 30% or so, I think you're pretty much there if you pull out that debt extinguishmen
componenttext: And then wondering how you're thinking about incremental margins, and maybe we get Brad involved in this into 2011 and the volume leverage in the business typically around 30% or so, I think you're pretty much there if you pull out that debt extinguishment item in this quarter. You've got the centralization, cost savings, potentially on top of that and the other side as you pointed out in your opening comments, you've moved R&D up a little bit, you've moved emerging markets investments up a little bit as well. But as we go into 2011, should we think about incrementals in that normal 30% range because the incremental savings are going to be offset with incremental investment? Or do you see a little bit more drop through next year as the savings start to move ahead of the incremental investments?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess, Terry, what I would say is third quarter is more likely we'd expect going forward. So earlier in the year, first half of the year, let's say, we were converting volume at a higher lever drop through. And the third quarter, you're right, it's abou
componenttext: I guess, Terry, what I would say is third quarter is more likely we'd expect going forward. So earlier in the year, first half of the year, let's say, we were converting volume at a higher lever drop through. And the third quarter, you're right, it's about at that 30%, a little over 30% range. And as I think about going into next year, given the investments we're making. Dave's talked about investments in our Solar business. We continue to invest in Knowles, a lot of different investments in all our energy space, I would see that we'll continue to do that for growth, and therefore, the incremental drop through should be more in that low 30% range. That's where I see it.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: And maybe just to clarify, the impact on growth I think once generally multi-industry companies get through the turn of cycle, you see organic moderate back to the mid-singles. Does your growth investments and you talked about Knowles as one example of th
componenttext: And maybe just to clarify, the impact on growth I think once generally multi-industry companies get through the turn of cycle, you see organic moderate back to the mid-singles. Does your growth investments and you talked about Knowles as one example of that, next year with the Apple opportunity and maybe more closer to that 20% range. Do you move the overall organic for the company into the upper singles as you get into that normalized environment? Were you offsetting some pressures on the maturing parts of the portfolio just to stay in that mid-single range?

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think you have to recognize that going into 2011, at least from our perspective, we see ourselves beyond the recession and beyond the balance. If you want to look at the first half of '10 incorporating some type of balance from the downturn. And now we'
componenttext: I think you have to recognize that going into 2011, at least from our perspective, we see ourselves beyond the recession and beyond the balance. If you want to look at the first half of '10 incorporating some type of balance from the downturn. And now we're in the early years of whatever that up cycle is going to look like. We've given long-range guidance. We did this a year ago at Dover Day of 4% to 5% organic growth longer-term through the cycle. I would expect -- I think we all expect that in the early years of the cycle that the growth rate could be a little bit better than the 4% or 5%. Anything beyond that, I'm going to defer to some commentary around Dover day. And we are going to provide a framework, not only for next year, but how we're looking at the next two to three years as part of our dialogue at Dover Day.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your final question comes from the line of Shannon O'Callaghan with Nomura.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your final question comes from the line of Shannon O'Callaghan with Nomura.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, don't look at the rate of improvement in margins at Electronic Technologies 2010 versus 2009. It's something that we can repeat again next year. But if you look at the range, it has a lot to do with product mix. It has a lot to do with customer mix
componenttext: Well, don't look at the rate of improvement in margins at Electronic Technologies 2010 versus 2009. It's something that we can repeat again next year. But if you look at the range, it has a lot to do with product mix. It has a lot to do with customer mix and it has a lot to do with where you are in the cycle. Absent a very strong downturn, we do believe that structurally, we've got the portfolio and the market balance. Market balance is important here to see the operating margins at DEP being 14% to 18% maybe, Dave, in a really strong period they may nudge a bit higher. But do not sit here and anticipate another 300 or 400 basis point improvement in margins.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, I said absent a very strong [indiscernible]. If you look at the downturn that we encountered last year, and gosh, I don't care what your product mix or customer mix looks like, when the customers actually stop ordering, it's hard to maintain margins.
componenttext: No, I said absent a very strong [indiscernible]. If you look at the downturn that we encountered last year, and gosh, I don't care what your product mix or customer mix looks like, when the customers actually stop ordering, it's hard to maintain margins.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think the only one I'm going to respond to is the end market outlook. You're right, we have continued to see increased North America rig count deployment throughout the year. We even continue to see a very modest increase in the third quarter. We think
componenttext: I think the only one I'm going to respond to is the end market outlook. You're right, we have continued to see increased North America rig count deployment throughout the year. We even continue to see a very modest increase in the third quarter. We think there could be another modest increase in rig count deployment in the fourth quarter. As we look at 2011 and all the data and the forecast from the experts that we're seeing and reading, best case, further modest increase in rig count deployment in 2011. It is not going to be as anywhere near the increase in 2011 like we have seen in 2010 with year-over-year comps.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: That was our final question. I'll now turn the call back over to management for any closing remarks.
componenttext: That was our final question. I'll now turn the call back over to management for any closing remarks.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jackie. This concludes our conference call. With that, we'd like to thank you for your continued interest in Dover, and we look forward to speaking again to you next quarter. And hopefully seeing you at Dover Day. So thanks for your attention toda
componenttext: Thanks, Jackie. This concludes our conference call. With that, we'd like to thank you for your continued interest in Dover, and we look forward to speaking again to you next quarter. And hopefully seeing you at Dover Day. So thanks for your attention today. Goodbye.

headline: Dover Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you. That concludes today's Third Quarter 2010 Dover Corp. Earnings Conference Call. You may now disconnect your lines at this time, and have a wonderful day.
componenttext: Thank you. That concludes today's Third Quarter 2010 Dover Corp. Earnings Conference Call. You may now disconnect your lines at this time, and have a wonderful day.
